B000VXVWUI|4.0|This is a review of the 1994 digital remaster. I like the sound quality on this version although I don't have any points of comparison for it.  On first listen I would have given this album 72.5/100 but on second listen bumped it up to 75/100. I'd describe the music on the album as interstellar space folk-rock, experimental, soundscapes, genteel, plonking noises, fx. It's mostly instrumental. Has a relaxing atmosphere which is occasionally broken by grating noises. The studio album runs to 46:57 minutes long on one cd and the live album, which is mostly relaxing versions of their earlier material comes in at 39:21 minutes.      The studio album -      Sisyphus:    Part 1 - I've marked it down this part as being 1:08 though Wikipedia gives it a different run time. A symphonic instrumental. An Emperor march type track (I'm not even sure that phrase exists...if it does, hopefully my use of the term is apt!). Has big drum sounds, which makes me think of something imperial in any case. Might have a synthesiser. Violins and Cymbals.    Part 2 - mostly a piano piece. My notes say that this follows on from the first part without a gap, which may explain why my time length differs from Wikipedia's entry for this album. Percussion does appear later on this track...cymbals and drums. Piano has a slow-medium tempo. Track becomes more violent towards the end with the percussion and chords on the piano.    Part 3 - experimental instrumental...plucked strings, percussion on metal objects and drums, sort of animal noises (or weird human ones...sometimes it sounds like someone has inhaled helium gas and started singing!), piano?    Part 4 - symphonic, slow tempo song. Sombre tone but with some ambient noises, a la meditation music. Has sounds of twittering birds but also a jolting transition from peaceful to loud music. Maybe you could describe this piece has having three movements (?). What I take to be the third movement is relaxing.    Grantchester Meadows - has ambient naturesounds...birds twiitering, insects. The ending has an amusing bookend to this use. Dual acoustic guitars playing genteel notes.    Several species of small furry animals gathered together in a cave and grooving with a pict - if they released this song as a single, they'd just have had to sing the title once for the needle to have reached the end of the vinyl!  Anyway, it sounds like ambient jungle sounds from another planet. Early on you get weird tapping percussion. Track is a bit schizophrenic at times. Sounds like a Scottish explorer or something at the end of the track. You also get experimental scat sounds and what sounds like UFO noises...presumably. I have never heard UFO noises myself.     The narrow way:    Part 1 - jarring bookends but pleasant dual acoustic guitar notes in-between. Some squeaky noises recalls their debut album. UFO sounds reappear for the intro and the outro to this track.     Part 2 - sort of Black Sabbath type proto-metal then mixed with spacey sounds. Bongo percussion.    Part 3 - a bagpipe sounding synth (presumably). Dave Gilmour sings, I think. Slow-medium tempo. Piano, cello? twangy guitar, woodwind type instruments, electric guitar at the end, bass and some solid drumming.    The Grand Vizier's garden party:    Part 1: Entrance - 1:00 minute long. Dual woodwind type instruments. Jarring military style drum/drum roll.    Part 2: Entertainment - Experimental. Like the drum intro and the tone of the drum...watery! Drums bookend this track. A candidate for my drum songs list, especially for the drum outro, which is good. Small passage in the middle of the track which has a grating, fingernails down the blackboard sound. A more experimental soundscape later. There are other ringing type noises in the track.     Part 3: Exit - 0:38 minutes long. Peaceful track with dual woodwind type instruments...recorder?      Live album:      Astronomy domine - 8:29. Seems pretty faithful to the original. Studio quality sound. Relaxing track. A percussion strong piece...cymbals etc. You only hear the crowd at the end of the track.    Careful with that axe, Eugene - 8:50. Crowd sound faint at the start. Mostly an instrumental, with just a few words and a little scat. The scream in this track prefigures that used on their \\"The wall\\" album. Sombre. Violins, organ and cymbals. Crowd sound louder at the end of the track. I heard a pop on my cd at 0:24 minutes in, I think.    Set the controls for the heart of the sun - 9:12. No crowd noises on this one. Genteel track, especially the vocals. Keyboard, hand percussion on interesting sounding drums. Big drums are used too.     A saucerful of secrets - 12:48.  Got a note questioning if this is a new track. They released an album by this name right after their debut...can't remember if this was on it or not. Probably not, going on memory. Another contender for my drum songs list...this track has a bit of a \\"Dance with the devil\\" vibe to it (Cozy Powell drum solo track) as far as the rhythm goes. An instrumental pretty much, but has some vocalising at the end. Organ, bassy, cymbals. Genteel for the most part but gets noisier later. Surf Guitar sound at times and maybe they  have a sort of Jimi Hendrix vibe to them as well.      Pink Floyd recommendations:      More. 4/5. Experimental album at times, but a couple of their heaviest rock songs thrown into the mix as well. Some genteel tracks too.    The wall. 9+/10. A concept album with an actual concept. Polished double cd release.    The piper at the gates of dawn. 7.5+/10. Strangely compelling debut album. Whimsical.
B0007LXPBI|5.0|When this movie came out in 1998, I was seven years old: so, I'm a part of the original target audience.  And I grew up with this film, ever since it aired on TV.  But I'm pretty sure that I'd still adore \\"The Parent Trap\\" if it wasn't a nostalgic childhood memory; it's one of those rare films that actually holds something for all ages.    Of course, the plot is quite fantastical and doesn't bear too much scrunity; but you're not supposed to overthink the movie, just to sit back and enjoy it.  Several other reviewers have expressed distate for the idea that two parents could split and seperate twin daughters; yes, in reality, that would be a horrific situation.  But \\"The Parent Trap\\" isn't reality; it's a beautiful fantasy.  Certainly as a kid I wasn't at all worried by the parents' situation, I was too captivated by the fun and romance and luxury, and the fact that they were going to get back together to live happily ever after.      I must make special mention the mother Elizabeth James (wonderfully played by the late Natasha Richardson), who is surely the idealized image of a mother; loving, a beautiful and elegant wedding-gown designer, and with a mischeivous streak to match her daughters.  The only downside to Richardson's great portrayal is that surely no real mother could measure up to this Hollywoodified image.    Of course that's the other concern; that the movie will set children who come from broken homes up for disappointment, when real life doesn't turn out like the movie.  But director Nancy Myers cleverly works against this by making both girls come from rich families, setting the story firmly in fantasy.  This also allows for beautiful sets and supporting characters of the butler and the nanny, played charmingly by Simon Kunz and Lisa Ann Walter.  I remember being fascinated by the beautiful London townhouse with all its ornaments.    As for any other concerns about the film not being child-friendly, I think they're misplaced.    -Yes, the baddie Meredith is a hot young thing; but as a kid, the only impression her flirting with Nick made on me was that I disliked her more (and the one line \\"That's why they have Do Not Disturb signs...\\" should go over the heads of anyone too young to know about that)  -Yes, the film includes alcohol; Nick Parker owns a vineyard of course.  But the scene in which Hallie (pretending to be Annie) samples some wine is harmless; she's taste-testing, not throwing it back, and it's a comedic moment as she shows off Hallie's knowledge of wine (which Annie should lack).  As for Elizabeth's drunk scene, it's hilarious, and it's not exactly going to corrupt the youth.  Mum's terrified of seeing Dad again because she's secretly still in love with him, so she has a little too much vodka...So what, really?  I watched that scene when I was little, and I for one haven't grown up to be a raging alcoholic.  In my opinion, Elizabeth is more of a lady than Maureen O'Hara in the original film, leaving her bra lying around the father's house!  How is that 'child-friendly'?!      Basically, \\"The Parent Trap\\" is a beautiful, harmless family fantasy.  And more than that, it carries real emotional weight.  When both girls first meet the mother or father they've lived without for eleven years, it's a really beautiful moment; it sure brings  a tear to the eyes of my family.  And Lindsay Lohan really was a very talented little actress, her double performances are brilliant.    \\"The Parent Trap\\" is a movie with enough happiness and heart to make anyone want their own happily ever after.
B003YK42LQ|5.0|This is an excellent follow-up to Only By The Night!  I ABSOLUTELY LOVE every song on this cd!  I didn't think they'd try to make another album like the previous one because that's not how they are as artists, they didn't and what a GRAND success!  There's a mix of all of their previous sounds, but still distinct, and it sounds great!  If you've not bought it yet, do so IMMEDIATELY, you won't be disappointed at all!
B002ZG981E|5.0|Inception is a great thriller that is original, intelligent, and worth the price of admittance.  It is a movie that demands participation of the viewer.  This is the case of any real \\"think of the possibilities\\" film.  Anyone who expects the film to unfold in simple terms will not only be disappointed, but will not understand the content.  This is the reason the film is getting some bad reviews on Amazon.  There are those who are unable to get involved in film and would rather have some monster running around gutting a cast of guest victims (the lowest common denominator).      Inception deals with dreams and the layered dream world affect on space and time.  The special effects are well rendered, but the real thrust of the film is the storyline.  If the viewer enters the world of Inception with a mind to follow its complexities, the film will not only prove itself worthy of a top rating, it will open the neurotransmitters of the mind and send the intelligent on a trip they will not soon forget.  In other words, this is not a film for the common dullard who will not understand what the heck is happening.  For more in the dullard perspective, read the one star reviews.    The blue ray disk has excellent extras, including a great 50 minute documentary on dream states. Beyond the talking heads, the visuals are akin to an acid trip.  The whole package is well worth the ride.

0307595579|3.0|Bouquets first - I really enjoyed 3/4 of the first book and I finished the other two in quick succession to satisfy my curiosity and found them to be enjoyable. I haven't read any books set in Sweden so I reveled in the author's descriptions, as it is an unfamiliar place to me and I could easily imagine the settings he was writing about. The premise the initial book was built around i.e. solving an old mystery/disappearance was intriguing to begin with.Lisbeth Salander is an interesting character and her background story (which helps explain a lot of her actions)is revealed gradually and is well rounded and fascinating.<br />Brickbats - well I can't be specific as that would spoil it for those who haven't read the books so I'll just generalise. The fact that the books are very popular is neither here nor there but anything that gets more people reading like the aforementioned Dan Brown with The DaVinci Code can only be a good thing.<br />Like a good popcorn movie blockbuster if you just want to be entertained, not think too hard and don't expect literary greatness, but want something to read on the aeroplane or on a sun lounge next to the pool, these books will do nicely.
B003EYVXTG|5.0|Ms. Granik, the film's director, had the good sense to select one of America's better writers on the dark side of rural life, Daniel Woodrell. as a source for her film. She appears to have let his sensibility have a large role in Winter's Bone, and I think in this instance it was a good decision.    For me, the strongest element was Granik's choice to stay intensely and consistently focused on the main character and her milieu. The viewer is never distracted by extraneous elements or stylistic sops thrown in to appease Hollywood conventionality. I was riveted throughout the film, even as the outcome of the main unseen character became evident, the denouement.    Credit goes to the filmmakers for studiously avoiding the showing of the beating of one of the characters - we do see the aftermath, and that is brutal enough. Also the scene involving a murder victim and the prolonged attention to the corpse is shot indirectly, and is all the more horrific as a result. As the ancient Greeks knew, violence is best implied off stage, and all the more effective as a result. Granik's camera had better ways to address violence.    In addition, the dysfunctional male hill culture is portrayed without condescension, as is the omnipresence of way too many guns. We're left to draw our conclusions about the impoverished, backward way of life and its struggling denizens amidst one of the most lethal drug epidemics to have ravaged the poor, white working class.

B000HEWEJO|5.0|My review is from [[ASIN:B000HEWEJO the 60th Anniversary Edition]].  The film is also available in [[ASIN:B000VDDDVO a 2 disc colorized set]] and on [[ASIN:B001UHOWXI Blu-ray]].    The movie that will forever be director Frank Capra's masterpiece.  \\"It's a Wonderful Life\\" is a fantastic story of a man with big dreams that he watches slip away as life's responsibilities take hold of him.  We watch George Bailey (Jimmy Stewart) go from wide-eyed dreamer to a broken man convinced the world would be a better place without him.  Stewart shows fantastic range in the movie, which is not the pure, sappy, feel-good movie it is so frequently portrayed as.  It has those elements, but there is also a dark side to the movie that is often overlooked.  This is my all-time favorite film, bar none.  And while most people view it as a Christmas movie, I think it should be enjoyed all year long.    The 60th Anniversary Edition has a beautiful black and white presentation of the film.  For bonus features you get the original trailer and two featurettes - \\"A Personal Remembrance\\" with Frank Capra Jr. and \\"The Making of...\\" hosted by (the late) Tom Bosley.  Both are rather old (early 1990s) but still very interesting.  The newer 2 disc edition contains this same DVD along with a second disc containing a colorized version of the film.  Unless you're a fan of colorized movies, I'd recommend saving your money and picking up the 60th Anniversary Edition.  The Blu-ray has the same contents as the 2 disc DVD.

Colors are subtle, and not a speck of dust is visible. Hard to imagine how this could look any better at home.    Watch out for the soundtrack! I will return to this disc again and again.

B004A8ZWSS|3.0|Angelina Jolie's appearance in \\"The Tourist\\" may someday set records for sheer photogenic appeal. She plays one of the most glamorous undercover agents ever to grace the silver screen; her wardrobe, her makeup, and her hair are all immaculate, and for some strange reason, they stay that way all 103 minutes of the film. Even when her character is roughed up by an odious mobster near the end, she still looks as if she has been prepped for a \\"Vanity Fair\\" photo shoot. This is, of course, a testament to her beauty as well as to the capable hands of her makeup artists, her hairdressers, and costume designer Colleen Atwood. Credit also to co-writer/director Florian Henkel von Donnersmarck for letting the camera linger on her face and figure a little longer than necessary. He clearly knew what the people wanted to see.    But where does that leave the film itself? Is it supposed to be less about plot and more about serving as an extended fashion show? This is one of the few action thrillers that doesn't get away with being preposterous, for it doesn't have the conviction to go all out with it. Unlike Jolie's previous action film, \\"Salt,\\" \\"The Tourist\\" is timid and flimsy. The stunts are never daring enough, the romance isn't passionate enough, and the sense of humor is so reserved that it seems completely out of place. The story is exceedingly simple, pretty much to the point that it barely holds our interest. Worst of all is the lack of onscreen chemistry between Jolie and costar Johnny Depp. The only real credit I can give it is for its beautiful cinematography and breathtaking scenery, the canals and Byzantine architecture of Venice shot with the same care and precision of an Italian tourism commercial.    In the film, Jolie plays Elsie Clifton-Ward, a British beauty who cunningly misleads a federal investigation of her former lover, the unseen Alexander Pearce, a career criminal wanted in many countries by many people. This includes the heatless gangster Reginald Shaw(Steve Berkoff), who he embezzled billions from. Scotland Yard's Inspector John Acheson (Paul Bettany) has been keeping tabs on Elsie for two years in the desperate hope that she will lead them to Pearce; for reasons never adequately explained, he's driven to capture the elusive criminal and bring him to justice. Pearce stays in touch with Elsie through a series of handwritten notes, which are delivered in plain but neat white envelopes. Her latest instructions: Board a train from Paris to Venice, and along the way, throw off the authorities by seeking out and befriending a man with Pearce's height and build.    Here enters Frank Tupelo (Depp), a nervous math teacher from Wisconsin hoping to forget a personal tragedy. He reads a spy novel. He puffs away on an electronic cigarette. He fumbles for his words like a man on his first blind date. Elsie regards Frank calmly, all the while calculating every move. They arrive in Venice. She convinces him to accompany her to a hotel and stay in her luxury suite - and, of course, he'll have to sleep on the sofa. In the aftermath of an intimate dinner and a few drinks, they kiss on the balcony. The next morning, while Elsie is out, a group of strange men barge into the suite intent on killing Frank, believing he's Pearce. And so begins the thriller portion of the film, highlighted by awkward action sequences, a contrived romance, and curious sudden appearances by Rufus Sewell. I leave it to you to discover whether or not his character is red herring.    \\"The Tourist,\\" a remake of the French film \\"Anthony Zimmer,\\" has all the reliable crime thriller clichés, including exotic locations, mobsters, a train ride, a mystery woman, and an apparent case of mistaken identity. It even has Timothy Dalton, although his role doesn't require him to be James Bond once again; he plays Chief Inspector Jones, who finds Acheson incredibly irritating and seems to take great pleasure in telling him off at the end. But even with all this at hand, something is missing. For something meant to be thrilling, we never quite go beyond the image of Johnny Depp running barefoot across loosely tiled Venetian rooftops. The blood never really pumps. The adrenaline never really rushes. It's all so flat and tired and insipid - not at all what I expected from a movie like this.    There is, of course, an inevitable plot twist, one that surprised me by not being surprising. Perhaps that was shortsighted on my part. Considering everything that happens, considering what was said, considering what we're shown, could the film have ended any other way? Crime thrillers are constructed with the intention of misdirecting the audience before revealing the truth. What bothers me is that this movie makes no real effort to trick us; it leads to a conclusion that was obvious from the very start. With no good romantic subplot, with no decent action sequences, and with no engaging plot, what else is there? The more I think about \\"The Tourist,\\" the more I return to its star, Angelina Jolie, whose beauty thoroughly overshadows everything else. That's not much of a compliment for the film itself, but it's the best I can do.

0307454541|4.0|A riveting tale by an author who lived -- and perhaps died by -- the story of a muckraking journalist and his genius research assistant who must wend their way through the dangerous worlds of high-stakes businessmen and their passions, prejudices and dark crimes. Lisbeth Salander, an adult-Goth version of Pippi Longstocking, demonstrates the creative pluck and toughness that makes her one of the best new heroines in fiction. The book starts slow and easy, and many readers might set it aside, but they'd miss the growing tension that finally gives the story a can't-put-it-down excitement. It has captured the hearts of millions of readers as well as the creative forces of Hollywood (who will release a second film version of the story in as many years, this time for English-speaking audiences). Highly recommended.

B002VECM72|3.0|The Blind Side (2009) is one of those heartstrings-pulling, feel-good, underdog sports movies that we get every few years from Hollywood. It tries, like so many films before it, to mimic the success of Hoosiers (1987) and Rudy (1993). And I'm surprised to say that this one works! Or at least better than most. I give it 3.5 stars out of 5. While it's not quite at the level that Hoosiers and Rudy share, it's the closest I've seen a sports movie get since them. As one of the ten films nominated in 2009 for the Best Picture Oscar, The Blind Side is really the story of the American Dream that we all idealize and strive for. It's the story of a talented young black athlete named Michael Oher who has challenges in school and at home. But what he needs is someone to help him dig himself out of the deep hole of problems he's been thrown into by his parents and society. Sandra Bullock, as Leigh Anne Tuohy, is the \\"lifeguard\\" that recognizes Michael's needs and she comes to his rescue, offering him a nurturing and safe place to live and a better high school to attend. She sees the love inside Michael and his unique talents for protecting those that he loves. He just needs to learn how to combine those talents with his natural athletic abilities so that he can perform at a high level on the football field, where he is pushed to perform due to his physical size.<br /><br />I can see why Sandra Bullock won her Best Actress Oscar for her role as Leigh Anne Tuohy in this film. She is at the top of her game here like I haven't seen her since Speed (1994) and A Time To Kill (1996). She's been taking a lot of romantic comedies over the past decade, and her acting just wasn't going anywhere in those roles, even though her films had marginal financial success and she gained vast name recognition. It's with The Blind Side that she has taken the talent we've seen in her supporting roles and brought it to a leading role. After seeing The Blind Side this Fall, I'm not sure I agree with Bullock winning her Oscar for this role, but once again, I think the Academy was really awarding her for her body of work, which has culminated so far with The Blind Side.<br /><br />The Blind Side is another great looking film with beautiful cinematography and good production design. I wouldn't say that Director of Photography Alar Kivilo broke any new ground photographically, but his work here is nicely lit and saturated to give the movie the warmth that its viewers certainly feel. I think one thing missing from elevating this great visual package is a more moving musical score. I can't remember that music elevated anything for me during this film. It wasn't a bad score, but it was merely serviceable and didn't elevate the emotional punch that this film strives for.<br /><br />All in all, The Blind Side is a great family film that has something for everyone. I especially love young actor Jae Head as S.J., the fun and precocious son of Sandra Bullock's character. His relationship with Michael as a brother is both endearing and hilarious. Some of the best scenes in the film are between S.J. and Michael. And many of the family scenes where the entire family is at home eating, watching TV, or just goofing off, reminded me of similar times in my own life and family. The Blind Side is the rare film that appeals to a broad audience, but doesn't sacrifice too much of the artistry and creativity in the craft of film either. It finds a nice balance that wins in many areas.ing her Oscar for this role, but once again, I think the Academy was really awarding her for her body of work, which has culminated so far with The Blind Side.    The Blind Side is another great looking film with beautiful cinematography and good production design. I wouldn't say that Director of Photography Alar Kivilo broke any new ground photographically, but his work here is nicely lit and saturated to give the movie the warmth that its viewers certainly feel. I think one thing missing from elevating this great visual package is a more moving musical score. I can't remember that music elevated anything for me during this film. It wasn't a bad score, but it was merely serviceable and didn't elevate the emotional punch that this film strives for.    All in all, The Blind Side is a great family film that has something for everyone. I especially love young actor Jae Head as S.J., the fun and precocious son of Sandra Bullock's character. His relationship with Michael as a brother is both endearing and hilarious. Some of the best scenes in the film are between S.J. and Michael. And many of the family scenes where the entire family is at home eating, watching TV, or just goofing off, reminded me of similar times in my own life and family. The Blind Side is the rare film that appeals to a broad audience, but doesn't sacrifice too much of the artistry and creativity in the craft of film either. It finds a nice balance that wins in many areas.

For the first time ever, the show disappointed me. (Warning: This review will contain some spoilers, so proceed with caution.)<br /><br />Season 5 picks up right where Season 4 left off...Dexter (Michael C. Hall) has discovered his wife Rita's dead body in the bathtub of their home, the final victim of the Trinity Killer. The only person who believes Dexter knows more about Rita than he's letting on is Quinn (Desmond Harrington), who does some digging into Dexter's personal life and eventually hires a shady private investigator to snoop around a bit more. However, Quinn's growing feelings for Debra (Jennifer Carpenter) force him to back off from Dexter, but it may be too late.<br /><br />Meanwhile, Dexter copes with being on his own, being a single father of three, and still finding time to devote to his Dark Passenger. He begins an unusual friendship with Lumen (guest star Julia Stiles), a young woman who has been through a terrible ordeal and becomes a way for Dexter to try and atone for Rita's death.<br /><br />The storyline in Season 5 is a good one, and I really liked the addition of Lumen's character, along with the budding relationship between Deb and Quinn. However, a lot of things annoyed me about this season. Angel and LaGuerta's characters drove me crazy the entire time. I always liked Angel and never liked Maria until she hooked up with Angel in Season 4, but this season Maria went back to being her usual conniving self, and the relationship drama between her and Angel was super boring. Also, I was looking forward to more \\"Dexter as a single dad\\" issues on the show, but the writers shooed Aster and Cody out the door in a few quick episodes. The writers don't seem to care if their plots have 50,000 holes in them. Too many things happened in the show that made no sense at all, and things that should have been dealt with on a much larger scale were just swept under the rug and forgotten about by all parties involved. Here are just a few examples:<br /><br />1. When Dexter and Lumen are in the warehouse and Deb shows up with her cop entourage, the vigilante duo have no problem slipping out of the warehouse sight unseen. Why didn't Miami Metro have the place surrounded? Makes no sense.<br /><br />2. What was up with Jordan Chase wearing Emily's blood around her neck? What really happened to her so many years ago, and why was she still so devoted to Jordan until the bitter end? Why didn't the writers explain ANY of this?!<br /><br />3. When Liddy turns up dead and Quinn refuses to answer questions and insists on getting a lawyer, everyone just forgets about that as soon as the blood on his shoe comes back as someone else's. Quinn just gets to walk away and go on with his life. Wouldn't Deb, Maria, or anyone else be a little curious about why Quinn's name was on Liddy's surveillance equipment or why Liddy called Quinn five times right before he was killed? No one seems to care about that at all.<br /><br />4. The biggest thing that bugs me is how close Deb came to catching Dexter in the act. The only way this season could have trumped Season 4 is if Deb had come face to face with Dexter and Lumen in the camp, and that didn't happen. Obviously Quinn knows that something is up with Dexter, but it seems like he's willing to keep his mouth shut because he loves Deb and because he's smart enough to stay on Dexter's good side. However, he or Deb really should have found out the truth about Dexter this time around. It needs to happen. In the books the series is based on,Deb finds out the truth about Dexter right away. Her obliviousness to the situation has dragged on for five seasons. It's time for her to wise up.<br /><br />I know I am being super critical, but I think \\"Dexter\\" is one of the best shows in all of television history, and I hold it to an extremely high standard. Season 5 did have its moments, and I really did enjoy it, but it was not the same standard of quality as the first four seasons of the show. I hope the writers get it together for Season 6, because I would hate to see this show die a slow and painful death.ness to the situation has dragged on for five seasons. 0930289234|5.0|A friend of mine once told me how frustrated she was at her friends when she showed them the movie \\"Casablanca\\".  They laughed at it because it was \\"so cliche\\"...and missed the point that this was *where* the cliches came from.  If you're a reader of comics who was *not* a reader of comics when The Watchmen first went to print, it might be easy to feel the same way.  Comics (or \\"Graphic Novels\\", if you wish) are not at all the same today that they were in the '80s.  They have changed a great deal, and The Watchmen was one of the early turning points.  It broke narrative down to move back and forth in time.  It changed storytelling by deftly flipping from \\"a constant stream of panels\\" to inserting pieces of scrapbook or newspaper article or other third-party way of communicating to the reader.  It also put together a fairly grim world that wasn't as black-and-white as the typical hero universe.<br /><br />In the world of 'The Watchmen', something changed in society, and people turned against superheroes.  Anyone who donned a mask and/or fought for the good guys is now either retired, undercover, has been banned.  Some capitalized on their fame, others labor under the 'blessing' of government surveillance.  The character 'Rorshach' is the plot's centerpiece:  watching from behind the scenes, Rorshach sees that a murder of one of their own has unraveled a pattern that hints at a global power play, and it is his fanatical determination to fight that helps draw back together what's left of the former team to which he belonged.<br /><br />That said, this story is not solely about him.  Instead it introduces a plethora of people--very human beneath their costumes--all of whom play a part in the final story.  Each is given intrigue and depth, and all slowly draw together to face the future.  Without giving you any spoilers, I will say that if there is one flaw in 'The Watchmen' it is a key plot twist that is rather awkward...it just didn't read well (and was handled differently in the movie).<br /><br />If you have seen the Watchmen movie, you won't see many surprises, but you will most likely enjoy 90% of this book.  If you are curious about what makes The Watchmen such a key piece of comic book history, keep in mind when you read something you've encountered before, it most likely happened here first.ntly in the movie).<br /><br />If you have seen the Watchmen movie, you won't see many surprises, but you will most likely enjoy 90% of this book.  If you are curious about what makes The Watchmen such a key piece of comic book history, keep in mind when you read something you've encountered before, it most likely happened here first.

B0027G783W|5.0|This is an outstanding CD, very sophisticated and thoughtful. It certainly reveals Moby as a master as a writer, musician, and arranger. Much of the work is haunting in its beauty or orchestral in is ambitions. There is a sense of sorrow or lament in many of the selections but these compositions are multi-faceted, taking the listener from grief to resolution or from sorrow to acceptance. It would be a big mistake to label this CD dark or sad for it moves beyond a single emotion.  The electronic instrumentation is lush and superb. Lush is a good word to describe these multi-layered compositions. Some selections are a bit hypnotic and trance evoking. The juxtaposition of vocal selections and instrumentals works perfectly in this CD for the listener is never startled as he transitions from one selection to another.  Like a multi-movement concerto, the CD is best when listened to in one setting. There is a sense of artistry and experimentation, as if Moby wished to push himself with this CD. The music combines southern blues and gospel from African American churches as well as chants from mystic choirs. Despite the fact that many accomplished vocalists were used to create this CD, the presentation is seamless with the vocals never taking over the instrumentals. It is hard for me to identify favorites, even though Wait For Me is outstanding. It is so nice to find a CD that is top rate from first song to last.

B004289ZW0|5.0|Like some, I bought the Wi-Fi only iPad because I specifically didn't want the 3G capability.  But  in hindsight, I did miss at least the  GPS capability. So to make up for my \\"remorse\\", I ordered the external bluetooth GNS 5870. It pairs quickly with the iPad buetooth and locked on to  6 satellites (based on one app's notification) through a large upstairs window in about 2 or 3 minutes. It was a little faster I believe through my car windshield. And it stayed locked on  even after walking briefly into a shopping mall with it in my shirt pocket.  How accurate? Two iPad  apps say accuracy is within 30 feet but this reading is through an apartment window. The accuracy of  Wi-Fi only was reported as 213 feet. But the GNS 5870  works very well all by itself and thats why five stars. I would not rate it less just because the \\"touch and slide\\" on and off is  slightly finicky and  can be unexpectedly activated by certain movements within a coat pocket etc. Its very portable at 1 3/4 x 3 inches and has a nice rubberized body except for the 1/2 inch wide plastic touch strip. The total GNS 5870 cost at $160.00, means I'm paying about $30.00 more than the iPad 3G model would have cost.    None of my views would matter though, if the GNS 5870 cannot work with the few iPad mapping, navigation, and GPS apps that are compatible with the Wi-Fi only iPad. So I discuss these apps not as an endorsement, but just to show that the GNS 5870  does work well without Wi-Fi and with no extra expense of a 3G data plan.  It should be noted however, that this does not replace the usefulness or maybe the overall accuracy of the iPad 3G, as the iPad 3G  has three modes of triangulation: Wi-Fi, 3G and GPS, which provide navigation assistance when some of the modes like satellite are not available. My uses however, may be in areas of no Wi-Fi and no cell towers. In this case, my Wi-Fi only IPad with the GNS 5870 will probably be as useful as the 3G model.     That said, I have tried all the following apps riding in my car with the GNS 5870 resting on the dash. The device tracks fine with the following apps that store map data internally in the iPad: Topo Maps, MotionX GPS HD and the iPhone app Navigon MyRegion. It also works fine with the iPad Google Maps but only in \\"classic\\" and \\"terrain\\" views.  This is because Google's map base is not stored internally in the iPad and must be first accessed on the fly through  Wi-Fi. The \\"satellite\\" and \\"hybrid\\" views are too large I believe to be cached in the app itself. For the same reasons, the GNS 5870 does not play well with Google Earth  because the app does not store large data fields internally.  But smaller, less memory intensive map areas  and routes in Google Maps (\\"classic\\" and \\"terrain\\")  can be cached and used later using only the GNS 5870.  These are erased from the cache however after any changes are made. The GNS 5870 works and tracks with the app Big World although this app also uses the Google Maps data base and I'm not sure how much of that map base is stored internally.     But if you are having Wi-Fi only iPad \\"buyers remorse\\",  and you still want  GPS, this is one excellent way to go. And if I get lost 30 feet from where I want to go then I'm in big trouble anyway.

B0045ODPKY|4.0|Ok, this is not a product review. I merely want to help you decide which version to buy.<br /><br />For the first time ever, I personally prefer a theatrical edition over an unrated director's cut, and I'll tell you why. The version shown in theaters was more fun, and made a lot more sense. Unlike typical director's cuts, this one doesn't just add cut footage and tweek some of the editing, it actually uses alternate takes, with alternate events and outcomes, that fundamentally change the story. Simply put, without giving spoilers, the director's cut is far more bleak, and makes the idea of a sequel fairly pointless (or at least insurmountable). In fact, the alternate takes, if one looks back on them, invalidate the entire reason for the story in the first place, making it all a redundant waste of time. Again, trying to avoid spoilers here, so let me just make up a silly analogy that will convey the idea. Imagine a convoluted story about trying to, say, poison a city's water supply, and in the director's cut version you discover afterwards that the bad guys just happened to have someone planted who, by happenstance, already works at the water plant and could have poisoned the water at any time over a lunch break. Seriously, it's that sort of stupid.<br /><br />I absolutely loved Salt when I saw it. It's a fantastic, exuberant movie that could easily be the start of a really enjoyable franchise. The director's cut, however, I did not enjoy. It did not add anything of substance beyond a few fairly insignificant scenes that were extended by a minute or two, and the alternate takes were far less satisfying than the originals, and only made the movie depressing and, honestly, rather stupid (and I'm far more partial to clever, intelligent stories that make sense). I truly believe that if you decide to go for the director's cut you'll be robbing yourself of seeing the vastly more logical and exciting story that was presented in the theatrical version.<br /><br />My recommendation: Go for the original, and avoid the director's cut. The latter is not an expanded product, it's an alternate story, and a bad one at that.<br /><br />Update: I've now had the chance to see the third version of this film (yes, a third unique version!), which I was unaware of when I wrote the above commentary. It's the \\"extended\\" version, and appears to only be available on the Blu-Ray disc. First off, unlike the Director's Cut, the Extended edition is actually a very good story. Some sequences are moved around or changed a bit, but this time it works, and the stupid elements have been removed (only one thing I disliked was retained, but at least in this version it had meaning). It also has a completely different final chapter, and I mean that in a big way, as in the story literally goes in a totally different direction, with new dialogue and scenes in other locations, etc.<br /><br />My original recommendation still holds, but I'd like to sum-up the three versions in this way:<br /><br />Theatrical: Overall best of the lot. Riveting story, exciting plot, lots of surprises and twists, and left wide-open for a sequel. (Also note that the sequel, which is already planned, will resume this version's storyline.)<br /><br />Director's Cut: Unsatisfying. The alternate material is more morose, and undermines the inherent logic of the plot. Ruins any real chance of sequel making any sense by turning it from Die Hard into David and Goliath (and David's got a broken arm and is near-sighted --and Goliath has a Death Star). Worth watching eventually for novelty's sake, but in my opinion not for entertainment value. Prime candidate for Rifftrax.<br /><br />Extended Edition: Very enjoyable. Combines most of the best elements of the Theatrical and Director's Cut, then slaps on a completely different ending. The style and sentiment seemed to be trying to emulate the neatly packaged, tidy spy stories of the '60s and '70s. This version ties the story up in a nice, neat bow of the instantly recognizable \\"divine justice\\" tradition (and you won't care, because it's just darned cool). This version is standalone and finite, with no hint at a sequel (and a sequel to this version would somewhat go against Salt's apparent wishes, but that's really all I can say without spoiling it for you). Definitely watch this version if you can get ahold of the Blu-Ray.<br /><br />Ok, that's enough outta me on this subject. I promise, I won't edit this again. :)won't care, because it's just darned cool). This version is standalone and finite, with no hint at a sequel (and a sequel to this version would somewhat go against Salt's apparent wishes, but that's really all I can say without spoiling it for you). Definitely watch this version if you can get ahold of the Blu-Ray.        Ok, that's enough outta me on this subject. I promise, I won't edit this again. :)

In Windows 7 - its much more intuitive, it automatically will clone the display on both screens and the audio auto outputs to the monitor/tv; if you just want the screen on the monitor only right click on desktop, click screen resolution and choose which monitor is the default. Of course she doesn't want to go - her life, her best friend, her potential boyfriend, her little brother and mom are in Atlanta. But Anna doesn't sulk for long, she quickly meets new friends and this one totally hot and totally unavailable boy Etienne St. Clair. I wonder what happens next;o)<br /><br />\\"Anna and the French Kiss\\" doesn't break any new ground, doesn't provide insight into anything of importance, it doesn't strive to be realistic or profound. 0756405890|4.0|This is a book for grown-ups who can appreciate a good story, don't mind putting in the time to read hundreds of pages, are strong enough to carry around a fat book, and can be patient enough with a young writer who starts at the end of the story to tell that same story through narrative told by the grown up in question.  If after all that you're still game (you should be), its a really good book.  I could not put it down.      I have been reading science fiction and fantasy for 38 years and sometimes it gets so predictable and thin that it sinks to the level of pringles - you know they won't be great but you want to eat them anyway.  Vampires, demons, shapeshifters, sarcasm and blood can get a little old.  It takes a lot to surprise me these days and a good writer to engage me.  This book engaged me, my brother and sister, my husband and several friends --- and those are just the folks I know.  It was surprising that Rothfuss writes beautifully, surprising that the story seems new and interesting, and surprising that it feels so sincere.  These things do not happen often.      Why not five stars?  It's his first book and I am not sure how #2 will be.  The most difficult part of The Name of the Wind is the length of time it's taking the sequel to come out.  Its hard to wait, but I literally come back to this part of the site over and over just to see if its ready yet.      That anticipation hasn't happened in a long time :)
B002G1YPH0|1.0|Ref:    - i5 750 CPU  - Cooler Master RR-B10-212P-G1 Hyper 212 Plus CPU Cooler  - Cooler Master Elite 330 case  - System operating at default    1st - This cooler does not fit the same manufacturer's mid tower case. The cooler extends 1/8\\" beyond the side panel. Go figure. A side panel mod will fix this.    2nd - The system operated at catastrophic temperatures. No matter which position this cooler is installed on the CPU, no matter what thermal compound [Cooler Master & others] is applied according to manufacturer's instructions, this cooler performed the following uniform and troubling results, in all cooler positions:    Idle: 55c-57c.  Stressed: 90c plus. [Stress test was immediately terminated].  These results can be system damaging.    The cooler was removed, the thermal compound was removed from the CPU and the cooler, re-applied and the cooler was reinstalled 90/180/270 degrees with the same results. Inspection of the the thermal compound on the cooler showed that only the 2 center heat pipes came in direct contact with the CPU. And those 2 center pipes only came in direct contact with the edges of the CPU.    I disassembled the entire build and removed the motherboard to detach the cooler mounting bracket.     I then reassembled the build and installed the Intel cooler. You know, the free one supplied with the CPU, that only takes a very few minutes to install. The Intel cooler performed the following results with the system operating at default settings:    Idle: 38c-41c  Stressed: 72c-75c  These results are reasonable, but I have always experienced lower temps with after market coolers in lieu of the CPU supplied coolers.    I am a firm believer of, \\"The cooler the system, the better\\" and I have always used Arctic Cooling Freezer Pro coolers, with their well machined base, with no problems. This time I thought that I would try a direct contact pipe cooler for this build. Maybe it was just a bad cooler. Maybe not! But, it now seems that it was a very poorchoice on my part.     All of this took several hours.     I won't be using this cooler again.

0198326769|4.0|Shelly Browne     Mr. Slater  English 9  13 December 2010    The Boy in the Striped Pajamas    In the book The Boy in the Striped Pajamas by John Boyne some of the conflicts that happened could have been explained a little better but over all it was an amazing book and I recommend it to all people. The book was easy to fallow what was happening and I wanted to keep reading it. It was published in New York in 2006.      The Boy in the Striped Pajamas had a good plot over all but in some of the events leading up to the climax were a little bit confusing and I think they could have been explained better. In the story Bruno and his family are living in there house in Berlin and they have the best house and friends. One day they come back from school and Maria their maid is packing up all their stuff and they figure out that they have to move to Out-With. When there at their new home its awful until Bruno walks along a fence behind their back yard and finds a friend in striped pajamas, Shamuel. Bruno brings him food and they talk every day but they can never cross the fence to play with each other. Until one day they find out that they are going to move back to Berlin because none of them like it in Out-with. When Bruno figures this our he decides to slip through the fence and play with his friend Shamuel.    The characterization and conflict in this story are well put together and it is very clear on the description of the characters and the conflict of the story. In the Boy in the Striped Pajamas Bruno is the main character. At the beginning of the story he has a really good life.  His grandparents live in Berlin with them and his house is the best for exploring and finding new places in their house. Then when they move to Out-With his grandparents are not there and there are no friends to play with, Bruno has a really boring life until he finds Shamuel but he is his only friend. The antagonist who is the Solders don't really change they keep doing the same things to the Jews until later but that isn't during the time period of the book. Bruno's father quit his job of being a solder at the end of the book and he realizes that his job is really bad.      The main theme that stood out to me in this book was treat others the way that you want to be treated because you never know what is going to happen in life. Something like this story will most likely never happen again in real life. But this theme can refer to things in everyday life. No one likes to be treated poorly so don't treat others that way and people wont be mean to you. It shows us a big message of what happened in the past and what life was like back then.      My overall Opinion of this book is that it was an amazing book even though it was sad. This story is really well written and because of that it makes it easy to understand. There is a lot of good detail but I think that there could be a little bit more detail to make it more emotional and to make a better picture of what is happening in your head. I also think they should have explained some of the big events that happened a little better. I really liked the story line and how they wrote the book and set it up.    Works Cited  Boyne, John. The Boy in the Striped Pajamas. New York, 2006.

B003L77GRO|4.0|I started watching Season Five with apprehension.  \\"How are they going to top the \\"Trinity Killer\\" seasons?\\" was my main thought, and, at first, I was somewhat disappointed.  I felt that the writers were definitely twisting the plot to suit their needs in a way that was not believable -- Dexter saying \\"It was me\\" when the police discover poor Rita in the bathtub -- and of course, Quinn being the character who is on to Dexter when no one else seems to be the least bit suspicious.  I mean, come on, Dexter has a work schedule that gives new meaning to the word \\"flextime\\" -- no one else thinks he's a little weird?  But the amazing Michael C. Hall has such a grip on me, holding me enthralled as a viewer, that I had to keep watching.<br /><br />And I was so glad I did.  Julia Stiles has to be my favorite guest actor yet in this remarkable series, and her performance was so compelling, I couldn't even wait to watch each episode On Demand.  I had to watch it on Sunday night at 9.  I loved the way she developed from a victim in the throes of posttraumatic shock, so emotionally devastated from her experience she can hardly function, to part of Team Dexter.  The chemistry between she and Hall was palpable, and Episode 11, the next to the last, had me on the edge of my seat.<br /><br />Johnny Lee Miller as the corrupt and totally despicable Jordan Chase was rivetting, as was the ex-cop turned criminal informant played by Peter Weller (one of the stellar supporting roles in this season).  Some have criticized Miller's lack of character development as a flaw in the season, but I think the writers had to keep the plot moving without dragging Season Five out too long.  This may have been done because Julia Stiles was, unfortunately, only available to them for one season.<br /><br />The fact that Season Five ended as it did, with Julia Stiles' character Lumen leaving, is why I can't give this five stars.  This definitely needed another season.  Quinn backs off, he is also given a reprieve that defies reality, and it's as if the writers were just in a hurry to tie up all the plot lines a little too neatly.  There were other instances that needed more fleshing out, too.  The relationship between Angel and LaGuerta is annoying; I can't figure out if he's sleeping on the couch or they're really separated.  Little hints are dropped, but nothing is really revealed. The character of the Nanny, played by Maria Doyle Kennedy, another fine actress, also needs more work.  We saw her fearless confrontation of Dexter when he leaves her with Harrison all night without so much as a phone call.  Then, she turns into Mary Poppins and even goes with Harrison to Orlando to stay with the grandparents.  Aster goes from a girl on the brink of juvenile deliquency and irrational hatred of Dexter to the sweet kid you always wanted her to be in the blink of an eye, too.  It's not a problem with the excellent acting or writing; it's a problem of too little time to do it all.  And that is a shame, because with a series of this caliber, nothing should be left on the cutting room floor.ty, and it's as if the writers were just in a hurry to tie up all the plot lines a little too neatly. And that is a shame, because with a series of this caliber, nothing should be left on the cutting room floor.

If I were to describe it in one word I would say, \\"Charming.\\" And that's not a word I like to use in conversatioin. The other word would be 'innocent.'    In my humble opinion, this movie is a thousand times better than Princess and the Frog. Princess and the Frog has some 'dark' elements to it, which really ruined it for me personally. While it isn't the most original movie ever, it holds its own in every aspect.     I went to a Saturday afternoon showing and I couldn't help but notice the audience particpation. For instance, when Rapunzel and Flynn went into the town and her hair was decorated with flowers and made managable thanks to little girls, the entire audience oohed and awed. I myself was blown away by that scene. Now I'm actually a 19 yr old guy - I love war movies, westerns, and good ole 'kid' movies. I really liked this movie.     The one thing I didn't appreciate was how inconsitent the evil Mother Gothel seemed. Sometimes she was like a true loving mom - if only for a brief time. It was just a little confusing and unsettling.     Also, I was suprised how well it 'got away with' all the musical scenes. Most movies today don't even try to do that anymore, and I like the fact that Tangled did decide to implement that seemingly forgotten technique.     Bottom line: It's a good, clean, light-hearted movie with great animation, character development, and vocal talent.   I would recommend this to anyone.

B00005QGAV|5.0|Of all the CD's I own, I find that \\"Dangerous\\" gives the listener a trip into music itself. The album is of course for entertainment purposes, but the music is a journey into music itself. The melodies, the lyrics are brilliant to the point that I consider this to be MJ's best album.    1. Jam. An electrifying start to the album. The lyrics say that world problems aren't enough to get MJ down.  The music video with Michael Jackson and Michael Jordan is really great as well. 10/10    2. Why You Wanna Trip On Me. This is a pretty good song after 30 or so listens. At first I really hated it, but   after taking time, and really reading the lyrics (which are about social ills), it really grew on me. 8/10    3. In the Closet. A very sexy song. Some might call it a little too mechanical, but in my opinion it's a very daring,  sexy song by Michael. The music video with Michael Jackson and Naomi Campbell is very sexy as well. 10/10    4. She Drives Me Wild. This song, features a rap by Aqil Davidson, who was a member of Wreckx-n-Effect. I felt that I didn't give this song much credit in my previous review. I have listened to this song over and over again, and I feel that this song, while not a great song, is not simply filler material. 7/10    5. Remember The Time. One of my favorite songs of this album. It's very fun, the lyrics are very simple, but the   music is so incredible. Of course, the ad libs are incredible. The music video with Michael Jackson, Eddie Murphy is really great. The scene with the Egyptian dancing and when MJ dissolves into sand at the end is very cool. 10/10    6. Can't Let Her Get Away. This song, I feel has been unfairly neglected. It has been called \\"MJ's worst song ever\\" by some, because of the overly repetitive lyrics. I was among those people. But I have, once again, listened carefully, read the lyrics carefully, and I have decided that this song is very overrated! Melody is powerful, and even though the lyrics tend to be over repetitive, someone told me that what I perceived as overly repetitive lyrics were suited to this song. So, I now like this song. 8/10    7. Heal The World. MJ was always dedicated to saving the world and making the world a better place. We should really listen to this song, read the lyrics and try to make a better world for the future. MJ said that he was so proud of this song. And he has good reason to. 10/10    8. Black Or White. This is one of those songs that will never change color, never fade away to dust with time. It's simply an eternal song, and not only that, the message about racial harmony is so uplifting. The music video, which is also known for it's comedy, is amazing. 10/10    9. Who Is It. This song is so similar to Billie Jean that it can almost be called Billie Jean 2. But where Billie Jean is very quiet, with emotion simmering beneath the surface, this song really lets the emotion flow out. Incredibly passionate, this song is my second favorite song from this album.  10/10    10. Give In To Me. This song which is the closest MJ has ever come to presenting a hard rock song, this song is amazing, and the guitar solo from Slash adds to the overall melancholy of the piece. This is a song that really has a combination of various levels of despair; fury, sadness, and melancholy. 10/10    11. Will You Be There. AMAZING. My favorite song of this album. Why? Because not only does it have the Ode To Joy part from Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, the angels singing, and the melody is so powerful, and MJ delivers this so perfectly, that it seems divine. 10/10    12. Keep The Faith. This is one of those songs that manages to uplift me when it's raining, when I'm having a hard day. Lyrics are inspirational, and MJ's vocals are amazing (of course!). 10/10    13. Gone Too Soon. Why do people say that this is sappy? This is a loving, heartfelt tribute to Ryan White, a victim of AIDS. His vocals are the perfect match to this piece. We all know how Usher sang this song at the Michael Jackson Memorial, and it was absolutely horrible (but the idea was so touching!) compared to MJ's. No one will ever come close to him! 10/10    14. Dangerous. This song, where MJ is more talking that singing at full power, is so seductive, and the perfect way to end the album. I recommend you check out MJ's performance at the 1995 MTV Awards. His dancing is amazing! 10/10    This gives a total score of 132/140, which is 94%, which means this is a GREAT album.    * * *    As I said before, this album presents a journey into music itself. Songs such as Jam, In The Closet, Remember The Time, She Drive Me Wild, Can't Let Her Get Away are for fun, and they are primarily intended to put the listeners in the mood for dancing. Songs such as Why You Wanna Trip On Me, Heal The World, Black Or White, Keep the Faith are inspirational. Songs such as Who Is It, Give In To Me, Will You Be There, Gone Too Soon, Dangerous are packed with emotion. With all these wonderful pieces, this is the album, along with Thriller and Bad, that will shadow the music industry with its sheer power. What would music be had it not been for Michael Joseph Jackson?

B000001ELD|3.0|I'm not a fan of Kiss because their music feels like nothing more than generic commerical rock to me, but Gene Simmons solo effort released in 1978 is a pretty decent album.  It's also a bit more diverse than a Kiss record.  However it's definitely lacking in truly great songwriting and guitar solos, which immediately separates it from Ace Frehley's solo album released the same year.    \\"Mister Make Believe\\" is a pretty good pop song.  It's extremely mellow, and not something you'd normally hear on a Kiss album so this might explain why I like it.   It's not quite a ballad though.  Probably my favorite song here.  \\"Burning Up With Fever\\" is a nice mid-tempo track with a nice chorus.  That's about the biggest compliment I can GIVE it though- it's just really nice.  It's not particularly *great*.  Nothing really interesting about the guitar playing despite the guest appearances either.  In fact what sounds like good guitar playing is completely buried in the mix so you can't really hear it anyway.  Bummer.    Perhaps one of the more underrated tracks is the semi-beautiful \\"Always Near You/Nowhere to Hide\\".  The verse melody is really sung in a great, compassionate kind of way, and despite its simplicity, it triggers a positive reaction out of me.  The gospel female chorus and hand claps at the end are a nice touch.  \\"Tunnel of Love\\" is a bit *too* simple and reminiscent of a mindless rocker for my tastes, but it's alright I suppose.  Just lower your expectations dramatically, haha.  The females during the chorus are fruity and pointless too.    \\"True Confessions\\" is a typical mid-tempo song with predictable lyrics about \\"temperatures rising\\".  I get tired of these kind of lyrics in rock songs.  It definitely gets boring after a while.  At least in the 70's those kind of mindless lyrics were considered relatively fresh since only a few bands were doing it.  By the time the 80's came around however... yikes.  Enough is enough.  As for the song, it's okay, but the femalevocals near the end are a little hard to tolerate because they keep repeating the same lines over and over again.  Come to think of it, this is basically the same exact song as \\"Tunnel of Love\\".    It takes a while for \\"Radioactive\\" to get going (an apparent tradition that originated on certain Kiss albums- it begins with weird, out of place sound effects).  Once the song DOES get going, well, it's mostly a repetitive chorus that keeps chugging along for the rest of the 3 minute time.  It's actually a good chorus though, so I'm not complaining.  For all you Kiss fans out there, this track sounds very much like a typical Kiss song.    \\"Living in Sin\\" is a pretty decent attempt at the glam rock genre.  Well then again, I guess most of the tracks on here are attempting to be like the glam rockers of the early 70's by artists such as David Bowie and Mott the Hoople.  This track is a notch better than most of the tracks on here but I can definitely do without the nonsense phone conversation taking place in the middle of it.      \\"Man of 1,000 Faces\\" contains a chorus that you can actually hum along to so that certainly makes it a quality track in my view.  Of course the chorus consists of nothing but an endless loop of repeating the name of the song over and over again.  However, it's too bad the song immediately turns generic after that 10-second opening guitar riff, but again, the chorus is the most noticeable feature so I guess I can't complain.  \\"See You Tonight\\" is pretty decent thanks to the uplifting vocal melody and the way sounds like a pop song.  Not quite the level of Paul McCartney though, but enjoyable nonetheless.    Overall, no, Gene Simmons first solo album is not a masterpiece (and neither are the rest of the solo albums by Kiss members released in 1978).  It's good enough to recommend however, and it's better in my opinion than the majority of Kiss's material.

I hated computers because of that; what a lousy interface that was; but I didn't hate the punch card operators ... I presumed they were all attractive young women working their way through college and I wanted to meet all of them.  Bemoan the hormones. Newman with the phrase printed below saying \\"What Me Wonder\\".  I'm supposed to fix my code and that's the only clue I get?  But I digress.    Why do I mention all of this?  Because some stupid Alfred E. Newman computer programmer type at Amazon.com decided I should review an audio book CD that I obviously didn't buy for myself (because they took my credit card number and I'm pretty sure that young kids who are interested in these stories don't have credit cards) -- I bought it for a grandchild for Pete's sake. Besides, if she does, and by the time she does, Amazon.com's hour glass will have run out and I wont be allowed to review the CD.  So ... He doesn't spend reading time with her now because all she has is printed matter to read and that's a little fatiguing for my son.  To give him a break, that's not because it's difficult for him to read; rather, it's because he reads at a level far exceeding the level most people are accustomed to, andespecially what children are accustomed to.  So this CD is a win-win for everybody: my son isn't fatigued; my granddaughter gets exposed to great literature; and the two of them spend some quality time with each other.    Now if you want more than 4 stars, you're going go have to ask my granddaughter.  I gave it four because I imagined it's great.  Only her imagination will know for sure, and I wont know until I speak with her at Christmas time.  If it gets my son to spend more time with his daughter then the CD is great no matter whatever other measure is applied.  In due time I'll know that also.

A BIG 5 STARS for this song!<br /><br />Better Than Revenge - What can I say this song is just amazing. The first time I heard this song I was surprised at some of the things Taylor was saying about this actress and how personal Taylor felt on the situation. I am pretty sure this song would be a great single especially to the women who've had another woman steal their man and they can't find a way of expressing their feelings. 0374158460|3.0|Not exactly the chronicle of our times the NYT and Time magazine reviews would have us all believe.  It was an easy, page-turner about a dysfunctional family.  Some nice turns of phrase, but I'll stick with The Corrections as my favorite Franzen.
B000001ELF|3.0|Ace Frehley at *least* had the sense to put together a collection of songs that's not as mindlessly simple and dumb in comparison to Gene Simmons solo album, for example.  Instead, Ace Frehley created an album with relatively catchy, upbeat, and rockin' tunes.      Perhaps most of Ace Frehley's solo album is an obvious attempt to copy the glam rock movement that artists such as Alice Cooper had already done, but at least these songs are written with more rock 'n roll energy compared to anything Kiss was doing at the time.      In addition to better songwriting and heavier songs, another aspect that makes Ace Frehley's 1978 solo album stand apart from the rest is his ability to lay down GREAT guitar solos.  After hearing Gene Simmons relatively flat and generic solo effort, *this* kind of guitar playing is definitely a welcome highlight.    \\"Rip It Out\\" starts out on an insanely heavy note, and it even has a memorable verse melody to back up that heavy chorus (which is great too, might I add).  The guitar solo is awesome.  I wish Kiss wrote more songs like these.  \\"Speedin' Back to My Baby\\" is definitely a ripoff of *something* but I can't recall the song I'm thinking of.  I'm leaning towards a Deep Purple song that's not coming to mind at the moment.  Either way, I love it.  Terrific vocal melody and equally terrific chorus.      \\"Snow Blind\\" (no, not a Black Sabbath cover version) continues the theme of being a thousand times better than anything Kiss had done up to this point.  I love the vocals once *again*.  Of course nothing Kiss-related can go by without something fairly annoying getting in the way, and in this case, \\"Ozone\\" is that slight annoyance.  Yes it's got a catchy vocal melody, but... that's pretty much all there is to it- a mindlessly repetitive line that never seems to change into something else.  It's alright though, but a guy like Alice Cooper would have known how to take a similar vocal melody and make it better.  At least side one ends on a great note with \\"What's on Your Mind?\\"  More excellent vocal work here.    The best song on the album HAS to be \\"New York Groove\\".  A chorus that's instantly likable, and just a great pop song.  Funny how I never heard of it until a few years ago though.  I wonder why classic rock radio has been ignoring it all these years?  \\"Wiped-Out\\" is another highlight on an album already choke-full of surprising highlights.  Yes, VERY surprising indeed.  I totally wasn't expecting such high quality from a band member of Kiss.  I guess the only truly forgettable song would be the closer titled \\"Fractured Mirror\\".  It's a 5-minute instrumental with nothing in the way of creativity and just passes by harmlessly, but also does so in a bland kind of way.    Yes, of the four solo Kiss albums of '78, THIS is the one you need to own.
0439023483|5.0|The United States is gone. North America has become Panem, a TV-dominated dictatorship, run by a city called the Capitol. The yearly highlight is the Hunger Games: a bloodthirsty reality TV show in which 24 teenagers chosen at random--two from each District--fight each other in a desolate environment called the ''arena.'' The story follows Katniss Everdeen, a girl from District 12 and Peeta Mellark, a guy also from District 12. who begin on an adventure they will never forget, The Hunger Games.    \\"Winning means fame and fortune. Losing means certain death. The Hunger Games have begun...\\"    Author Suzanne Collins keeps the romance moving and interesting throughout the novel involving Katness and two gentlemen. At times it's twisted, changing and confusing, but Collins keeps you involved and torn between which guy Katniss should choose and wondering if her feelings are true. At the end of the novel I was left heartbroken by a big reveal that I had been on edge about for a majority of the story. Collins then, without resolving the issue, ends the book! Oh, how cruel but suspenseful! I suggest having the next book ready and waiting.    Even though Collins is an amazing writer, she, like all authors, has her faults. Although the story line is intriguing and she keeps you emotionally involved, she tends to drag portions of the story on for longer than necessary and you start to think, \\"okay okay already: what's gonna happen next!\\"     I loved this novel! It's one of those that takes a long time in the beginning to get into only because Collins is being sneaky and getting the reader attached to each and every character. Then, wham, here is this story that  you've lost yourself in and if you're not careful you'll forget it's just a book!  Such a suspenseful, thrilling, and emotionally capturing book. I wholeheartedly recommend this book to all ages.
