B00192IV9U|4.0|Michael Jackson's MICHAEL<br /><br />To be perfectly honest, I've never been that much of a Michael Jackson fan ... or, at least, it's safe to say that I think his early solo stuff (up through BAD) was exceptional, but I think somewhere along the way he kinda/sorta lost his way musically but NEVER as a performer.  As others have already said elsewhere, there'll only be one Michael Jackson in many a generation.<br /><br />Still, in my opinion there's little earth-shattering here, despite the fact that this may be a large part and parcel of the last music Michael ever performed for his fans, and that may not be a bad thing.  For Michael, it was always about the music as much as it was about performing, and so much of his life was spent exploring his sound that I found much of MICHAEL just pleasant `listening music.'  For a master of his craft, MJ deserved to write and perform what he wanted, and that's largely the impression I take from this (possibly) final album.<br /><br />If anything, MICHAEL presents a bit of a historical throwback in Michael's career, perhaps back to a time when it was more about `the sound' than it was `the career.'  Much of this comes across as soft rock - the kind of territory Michael staked out early in his work - and that came as a welcome surprise.<br /><br />Hollywood Tonight: (2.5 out of 5)<br />Shades of THRILLER as Michael resorts to a spoken word bridge in `Hollywood Tonight,' the musical story about the search for fame and fortune.  Not the best choice as, outside of his backing vocal sounds, there isn't much here to distinguish itself from other superior tracks on this disc and elsewhere.<br /><br />Keep Your Head Up: (5 out of 5)<br />Vintage Michael vocals as he swoons lyrically - complete with a chorus - across this tale of musical inspiration, though a fair amount of it is a bit clich&eacute;d.  \\"Gimme your wings so we can fly.\\"  Still, this is the kind of stuff he could easily hit out of the park every time he sang.<br /><br />(I Like) The Way You Love Me: (3.5 out of 5)<br />There's a bit of an opening vocal story of Michael telling you what the song would sound like as opposed to the instrumentation comes across as a bit bizarre, but it finally gives way to the music and a adult `soft rock' vibe that's easy on the ears.  \\"I thank the heavens above that I met ya.\\"  Again, a bit clich&eacute;d and not nearly as strong as other tracks, but it's a harmless confection for your ears in Michael's gifted hands.<br /><br />Monster (Feat. 50 Cent): (3.5 out of 5)<br />Hate the softer, thoughtful-sounding refrain paired with the driving and fist-pumping main verses. Musically, I don't think it works as well as it could, especially given the message of fame corrupting and haunting the individual spirit.  Clearly, this is intended as a warning label about the dangers of celebrity. We make our own Frankensteins these days, and Michael was as much a victim of celebrity as any has ever been.<br /><br />Best of Joy: (1.5 out of 5)<br />Way too clich&eacute;d, way too disconnected, & way too predictable to really achieve much, `Best of Joy' is probably the weakest track here.  \\"We are forever\\" repeated over & over again sometimes is nothing more significant than \\"we are forever\\" repeated over & over again.  Michael will live forever, but, hopefully, this song won't.<br /><br />Breaking News: (2 out of 5)<br />Another personal statement from Michael, `Breaking News' opens with a montage of reporters and pundits announcing the latest bit and byte about the King of Pop. This is undoubtedly intended as an indictment of paparazzi destroying celebrity, but haven't we heard this message before, arguably even on this album? I give it a few props for the jazzy horns backing up the instrumental part, but, otherwise, it's still much too tame to be memorable.<br /><br />(I Can't Make It) Another Day (Feat. Lenny Kravitz): (5 out of 5)<br />OK, now this ROCKS, and I mean it's hip, groovy and magical in the way only Michael could ROCK.  Great soft verse rises to a powerful refrain backed with a soft Lenny Kravitz accompanying a masterful Michael.  \\"I can't make it another day ...\\" is a much more relevant lyric for Michael at this point in his life, and I'll always recall tune when I think of his final days.  An instant classic that can stand alongside anything Michael's done.<br /><br />Behind the Mask: (3.5 out of 5)<br />A synthesizer-infused Motown rhythm about life and love behind the mask.  \\"Who do you love?\\"  Again, the track is lifted by some great sax work and that certain toe-tapping appeal that distinguished Michael's craft throughout the years.<br /><br />Much Too Soon: (5 out of 5)<br />Beautifully soft guitar backed by a simple but wondrous musical arrangement, `Much Too Soon' is pure Michael ballad.  \\"Would you like to go with me, and she answered no to me, but I guess I learned my lesson much too soon.\\"  It ends as magically as it began.  This one deserves to stand the test of time, and it'll no doubt be found and appreciated by others for quite some time.<br /><br />Hold My Hand (Feat. Akon): (5 out of 5)<br />\\"This life don't last forever, so tell me what we're waiting for ...\\"  Is there any more relevant an opening line for a Michael Jackson song given the tragedy of his passing?  \\"The nights are getting darker, and there's no peace inside, so why make our life harder by fighting love tonight?\\"  Happiness is found together - between two lovers, between a singer and his song, between a performer and his audience - and that's the significance of this closing tune.hael.  \\"I can't make it another day ...\\" is a much more relevant lyric for Michael at this point in his life, and I'll always recall tune when I think of his final days.  An instant classic that can stand alongside anything Michael's done.    Behind the Mask: (3.5 out of 5)  A synthesizer-infused Motown rhythm about life and love behind the mask.  \\"Who do you love?\\"  Again, the track is lifted by some great sax work and that certain toe-tapping appeal that distinguished Michael's craft throughout the years.    Much Too Soon: (5 out of 5)  Beautifully soft guitar backed by a simple but wondrous musical arrangement, `Much Too Soon' is pure Michael ballad.  \\"Would you like to go with me, and she answered no to me, but I guess I learned my lesson much too soon.\\"  It ends as magically as it began.  This one deserves to stand the test of time, and it'll no doubt be found and appreciated by others for quite some time.    Hold My Hand (Feat. Akon): (5 out of 5)  \\"This life don't last forever, so tell me what we're waiting for ...\\"  Is there any more relevant an opening line for a Michael Jackson song given the tragedy of his passing?  \\"The nights are getting darker, and there's no peace inside, so why make our life harder by fighting love tonight?\\"  Happiness is found together - between two lovers, between a singer and his song, between a performer and his audience - and that's the significance of this closing tune.

B003L20ICE|5.0|In recent cinema, actors have failed to bring me to a sense where I genuinely cared about their characters. Even when they do a technically good acting job, they don't leave a sense of emotion, beauty, and enlightenment with you. They don't stay with you for long. They don't give you a reason, or a desire to return to the cinema and see their film again.     In The Kids Are All Right, Lisa Cholodenko paints a canvas of thoughtful characters, an insightful script, a beautiful Californian setting, and even though it's no special-effects laden, CGI-heavy typical summer entertainment, it brings you more than any film you've seen over the summer. It has fantastic acting from its adult and younger actors alike. As of the very moment, I have seen this film twice. And both times, I laughed my ass off, I cried, I felt the emotion of the characters, and I left the cinema with a true sense of enlightenment and optimism.     The film follows a married lesbian couple, Nic and Jules (Annette Bening and Julianne Moore) who have been together for many years. Their children, Joni and Lazer (Mia Wasikowska and Josh Hutcherson) are very happy, except they've always wondered about their biological father. They find their sperm donor, or father in Mark Ruffalo's Paul. Ruffalo seems somewhat typecast in the \\"idiot\\" parts, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, considering how well he plays it. The characters become bigger parts of each other's lives and butt heads, and without saying any more, people love, people hate, and they make mistakes.    Julianne Moore has certainly been on the top of her game in her recent work. With the few scenes she had in last winter's A Single Man, alongside powerhouse Colin Firth, and this spring's Chloe, alongside the surprising powerhouse Amanda Seyfried, and in this spring's season of Tina Fey's 30 Rock, great, even with a ridiculous Boston accent, she's been in top form. And Annette Bening, who I haven't seen for a while, also is fantastic in this film.You can believe that the two are a couple who have made it through the thick and the thin. The two ladies compliment each other very well.    However, the real heart of this film lies in Mia Wasikowska, who plays Joni, the older daughter. Her face really tells the story of the film. She says so much, without really saying anything at all. The recent Tim Burton remake of Alice In Wonderland being the only thing I remember seeing her in, I can tell you that she flexes her acting muscle more here. A scene near the film's end where her character leaves for college, you can see the emotion flooding her face, and it's a beautiful thing. Considering I'm a student who's about to leave for college in less than a month, perhaps I got more out of it than the average person would. Either way, it's an astounding performance.    One thing that sets this film apart from competing indie tragicomedies, is its mind. It has quite a bit of intelligence to it. And it's the perfect blend of comedy and drama. It may very well be this summer's equivalent to last year's (500) Days of Summer. A mix of wonderfully eclectic acting, an undeniably realistic feel, amazing acting from all of its cast, with a rockin' soundtrack, these Kids are more than all right.

There are some truly shocking developments and by the end of the finale, I was cheering out loud. If you dig the action of 300 and Gladiator, the Shakespearean wordplay of Deadwood, the conniving and backstabbing of Melrose Place, and the sort of soft core porn you might find late at night on Cinemax, you'll probably dig this show.

0307272702|5.0|I think a lot of people (myself included) who have struggled with weight gain and attempting to lose it for a long time keep hoping we'll pick up a book and the magic answer will be there on the first page in one paragraph and we'll finally know that THIS is what we need to do.  It's not spelled out in this book on the first page in one tidy paragraph, but I've never felt closer to a genuine explanation as I did while reading this book. There is detailed information on why we get fat that I feel is very accurate and informative.  You can't fix a problem if you aren't truly aware of what the problem is and this book is about gaining that awareness.  He explains the why part of it very thoroughly.  The final chapters are more centered on what to do about it.<br />Anyone who has struggled with weight loss knows that it is not just a matter of calories in calories out.  There are thin people who eat 5000 calories a day and never gain weight.  Their are overweight people who eat 1200 a day and can't seem to get any weight off.  It does matter what we are putting into our bodies as well and genetics play a huge part in it.  He goes into this in depth in the book with studies and comparisons.  There is a ton of information packed into this book, covering hormones, insulin, myths out there regarding diet, metabolic syndrome, exercise, meat or plants, etc.<br />This book is well worth the money it cost to buy it and the time spent on reading it.  It doesn't feel like a gimmick or infomercial when you are reading it like so many in the field do, it feels educational and you come away from reading it with genuine knowledge about your body and what it will take to change it.

0393051587|5.0|\\"A Christmas Carol\\" is not just A Christmas story, but one of THE Christmas stories.<br /><br />Not only is it instantly recognizable by pretty much everybody, but it's relentlessly copied and spoofed in countless Christmas specials. But taken just by itself, Charles Dickens' yuletide novella is a pretty bleak and bittersweet affair, with brilliant imagery and lots of ghostly weirdness. And the annotated edition is a brilliant supplement to the story.<br /><br />Scrooge is... well, a scrooge -- a professional miser who hates Christmas, goodwill, charity, puppies, kittens, his relatives, his employees, and virtually everything else except money.<br /><br />And on Christmas Eve, his dead partner Jacob Marley comes back, wrapped with supernatural chains, and claims that Scrooge is doomed to the same fate. But he has a chance at redemption: three ghosts representing will visit him that night, taking him on a guided tour of Christmases past, present and yet to come.<br /><br />So Scrooge is transported on a trio of hourlong trips through time. The childlike Ghost of Christmas Past takes him to his bleak childhood, when he was less jaded and hard. The jolly Ghost of Christmas Present takes him to people's homes on the very next morning, specifically of of his nephew and the poor miner Bob Cratchit. And finally a Ringwraith-like spirit gives him a glimpse of Christmas years in the future... a bleak and terrible future, unless he changes his ways.<br /><br />You can read plenty of symbolism into a story like \\"A Christmas Carol\\"; I've heard speculation about Dickens' father, the Industrial Revolution, spiritualism, and all sorts of other stuff. But at its heart, \\"A Christmas Carol\\" is the most powerful when appreciated for its story alone -- a story about a greedy, miserable man who redeems himself by learning to love all humanity.<br /><br />Dickens' writing is utterly brilliant here. Most of the book is bleak, grimy and painted in shadows, with Dickens only rarely holding back from showing the dark situation of England's poor. A great example is the symbolic children Want and Ignorance (\\"a stale and shrivelled hand, like that of age, had pinched, and twisted them, and pulled them into shreds\\"). As for the Grim-Reaperlike third ghost, it's the stuff of nightmares.<br /><br />But all isn't dark here. Occasionally Dickens splashes it with moments of crystalline brilliance (\\"It held a branch of fresh green holly in its hand; and... its dress trimmed with summer flowers\\"). And as dark as the book is, Dickens offers hope for the future.<br /><br />He also does a brilliant job with Scrooge, \\" a squeezing, wrenching, grasping, scraping, clutching, covetous, old sinner! Hard and sharp as flint, from which no steel had ever struck out generous fire.\\" Having worked hard to make us hate Scrooge, Dickens then deftly displays his skill at slowly revealing how Scrooge became who and what he is, and slowly redeeming him.<br /><br />So what is the annotated edition like? Really beautiful -- sturdy spine, smooth pages, beautifully reproduced pictures and photos, and LOTS of annotation to explain anything that might not be clear to modern readers. Um, almost too much annotation, since sometimes it seems longer than the actual text... but very enlightening if you don't know what inspired Marley's ghost's chains.<br /><br />Charles Dickens created one of the greatest Christmas stories with \\"A Christmas Carol\\" -- bah humbugs, merry Christmases and all. God bless us, every one!and's poor. A great example is the symbolic children Want and Ignorance (\\"a stale and shrivelled hand, like that of age, had pinched, and twisted them, and pulled them into shreds\\"). As for the Grim-Reaperlike third ghost, it's the stuff of nightmares.     But all isn't dark here. Occasionally Dickens splashes it with moments of crystalline brilliance (\\"It held a branch of fresh green holly in its hand; and... its dress trimmed with summer flowers\\"). And as dark as the book is, Dickens offers hope for the future.     He also does a brilliant job with Scrooge, \\" a squeezing, wrenching, grasping, scraping, clutching, covetous, old sinner! Hard and sharp as flint, from which no steel had ever struck out generous fire.\\" Having worked hard to make us hate Scrooge, Dickens then deftly displays his skill at slowly revealing how Scrooge became who and what he is, and slowly redeeming him.     So what is the annotated edition like? Really beautiful -- sturdy spine, smooth pages, beautifully reproduced pictures and photos, and LOTS of annotation to explain anything that might not be clear to modern readers. Um, almost too much annotation, since sometimes it seems longer than the actual text... but very enlightening if you don't know what inspired Marley's ghost's chains.     Charles Dickens created one of the greatest Christmas stories with \\"A Christmas Carol\\" -- bah humbugs, merry Christmases and all. God bless us, every one!

030746363X|5.0|I'll admit - I was very skeptical.  I kind of have a love-hate relationship with Tim Ferriss' work.  He often uses attention grabbing headlines/titles to lure me in and sometimes I resent that (Four Hour Work Week, c'mon).  You know the saying - fool me once shame on me...but despite having been lured in, the content keeps me coming back.  And this book delivers again - big time.      True to form - it's replete with the attention getting hooks - they almost look like a collection of spam headlines - but don't fear, there's nothing about buying foreclosures or refinancing your mortgage for 0% - but there is an encyclopedic amount of great information.  I have yet to get through the book and I'm not in a hurry either.  I think it is meant to be consumed and enjoyed over time - perhaps for many years to come - much of the information appears already to have withstood the test of time.    It is a thick reference book that I will put on a shelf and refer to frequently - and you should too.
0517548232|2.0|The arguments in this book are hugely plausible theories, but they run into a brick wall of fact.  In the second half of the 20th century, every government in the world that adopted Keynesian economics became enormously prosperous.  Every time a government tried the so called \\"free market\\" economics Hazlitt recommends the result was high unemployment and a concentration of wealth.  The sad fact is that some people are much, much better at making money than others, and that absent some government control, the rich wind up with everything and the workers with the bare minimum necessary to sustain life: the Iron Law of Wages.  There is no doubt that free-market capitalism is the best economic system in every arena where there is a profit to be made.  But the free market capitalists have to harden their hearts against the children, the elderly, the sick, and the victims of natural and man-made disasters, off whom no profit can be made.  If money is your most important value, Hazlitt is right.  But if you care about people, then Hazlitt is wrong.

Optimism is one thing, but this entire book as an ode to human selfishness and greed.  Your women got raped during war, well, you didn't have the right mind set, Blackwater made millions through wars, well, Erik Prince had the \\"right\\" mindset.  What a load of rubbish.  For those professing religious beliefs in Christianity, Islam, or Hinduism, you might find the book also problematic on moral grounds, as it never does account for events in everyone's lives, where other people's actions have directly impacted yours.  It basically blames the victims.  Going through Jim Crow and lynching, well, change your mindset and the oppressor class will automatically calibrate their behaviour towards you.  Donate the money to a soup kitchen instead of buying this book (oh wait, the homeless actually want to be homeless according to this book!)

030746363X|5.0|I bought the book to see what Tim has tried and what worked.  The various strength and muscle building sections are generally in the HIT (high-intensity training) camp where you work out hard in very little time (minutes) and infrequently (1-2 times per week in order to allow recovery) for maximum results (sort of the opposite of P90X which is too much work for the result).  The fat loss part is similarly easy to follow;  you won't go hungry (I felt surprisingly full all the time);  the main challenge is to only stock approved items (requires a little re-training of personal habits which takes a few days).    I've read a few of the negative reviews, which broadly fall into two camps:  1)  Tim has nothing new to say, just re-hashing existing material;  or 2)  the stuff can't work.  If it's nothing new, then it probably works; and if it doesn't work, then it's probably not well known existing material.  You can always try it and see if it works for you.
B002JCSWV6|4.0|As part of his program to inspire François Pienaar, played by Matt Damon, the captain of the South African rugby team; Nelson Mandela, played by Morgan Freeman, inculcates upon him an piece of literary wisdom that had inspired him to endure his 27 year imprisonment. During that time, Mandela learned all he could about the white people who had put him there by mastering their language and reading their books. In the process, he found a 19th Century poem which embodied the \\"unconquerable soul\\". This famous poem, from which the movie derives it's name, ends with these lines: \\"I am the master of my fate:I am the captain of my soul\\". The power and conviction of this poem moved Nelson Mandela and helped direct his life and goals.    In the movie, as apparently in life, Mandela, now as President of South Africa, develops an equally unconquerable passion for the national sport of rugby, which he uses to unite his country. The Springboks, a mostly white team, are cheered on by the white South Africans, but soundly \\"booed\\" by the blacks because of what they represent. However, Mandela sets about to change all that. His obsession with the sport and modus operandi tend to bewilder both his staff as well as his fellow black countrymen. Yet it is revealed it to be a brilliant move for Mandela, the struggling team, and for the whole country, both black and white. His impressively forgiving attitude toward the white power is demonstrated when he, for example, invites François Pienaar to the presidential office for tea and takes him under his wing. Will he have the power to set this poetry in motion and lead to victory? That is the question that this film answers.    I give this film 4 stars for the inspirational story, yet I personally find it to be rather syrupy, predictable and lacking in depth. For example, none of the real racial tension which could have made it more believable and powerful is seen in this movie. Nelson Mandela himself was no Mahatma Gandhi, but there was only one slight hint in this movie that he was less than a saint. Morgan Freedman played this role masterfully, though I found the Matt Damon character to be rather bland. So if you are just looking for a feel-good movie, without all the ugly reality, this is a good choice.

B004B8RXQQ|5.0|First off, I must admit to being a huge fan of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's work. I can understand that many find the introduction of Holmes into the 21st century somewhat disturbing in contrast with Doyle's representation of 19th century London. Certainly Doyle's original works are masterpieces. However, this series is far better than some of the reviews I have seen.    Yes, there are modern tools that we all use such as Google, smart phones, automobiles, guns, and other such gadgetry. However, the deductive reasoning employed by Holmes is timeless. This series illustrates that.    This is by far one of the most accurate portrayals of the Holmes epoch I have yet to encounter, although I will admit that Robert Downey Jr. did a very entertaining Sherlock, as did Jude Law as Dr. Watson. Their production was too much in the way of Hollywood explosions, naked women, and a Holmes character with a love interest that should not have been. Definitely not a mirror of Doyle's product. This series is all the more accurate even with being transcribed to our time. It is all the more true to the original design and to the motivations and intentions of the main characters.

B002VWNICW|5.0|*** REVIEW FOR THE 2010 BLU RAY VERSION ***<br /><br />In order to have this movie in High Definition, I've had the HD-DVD format of it for a few years now - but it's an America issue and has the controversially modern US ending. Now at last it arrives on BLU RAY in the USA (January 2010) and in the UK (May 2010) and it's just as gorgeous a transfer. It uses exactly the same elements that the HD-DVD did - even the same menus - and the extras from the DVD are all intact also (with the US ending tagged on as an Alternate).<br /><br />The improvement in picture quality is immense over the rather blurred DVD experience. As it opens with a misty dawn and the twitter of birds, we see the young and feisty Elizabeth Bennet (played with a magical touch and staggering assurance by Kiera Knightly) walking with a book. But it's not until she crosses the courtyard of her home that the real quality kicks in - and it's a wow. The picture takes you aback - it wasn't this good in the cinema I can tell you...<br /><br />It isn't perfect throughout by any means though. Because they were going for authenticity, a lot of the early evening and dark night sequences are shot in candlelit rooms (as they would have lived), so you get fuzziness in the definition... But once you get out into the countryside or inside one of the great halls of stately homes - where proper lighting prevailed - the picture quality is beautiful. There is one famous dream sequence where only Kiera's closed eyes fill the screen - she is dreaming of standing on the cliff edge - the clarity is gobsmacking. You also notice the weave of the clothing, the dirt on the hemlines, the ever so slightly unkempt hair - the attention to detail is great.<br /><br />Directed by Joe Wright and released in late 2005, the film version was living in the shadow of the legendary 6-part BBC production from 1995 - so the movie had a lot on its shoulders and admirably rose to the task. Another trump card was Dario Marianelli's lush piano score (Oscar nominated) swirling around the scenes like a graceful swan.<br /><br />In the cinema, it was a delight to look and experience - but sitting at home and watching it in real definition is a far more rewarding and illuminating experience. The acting chops on display is right across the board and apart from a slightly jarring ending, it had the hallmarks of a shoot that was fun and supremely confident in its delivery. I know others will cite the BBC production as definitive - but I think there's more than enough room on my shelf for both.<br /><br />Matthew MacFadyen, Brenda Blethyn, Rosamund Pike, Carey Mulligan, Judy Dench, Tom Hollander - they were a cleverly chosen cast - and Rupert Friend won the heart of the lovely Kiera (which might explain the ethereal beauty of her performance). But it's the stunning adaptation of Jane Austen's novel by DEBORAH MOGGACH that is the real hero of the day. There is a sequence when Elizabeth and Darcy finally face off against each other in the rain - the dialogue is to die for - and should have been Oscar rewarded. As a dabbler in screenplays myself, I can't stress enough just how good the work here is - dazzling stuff.<br /><br />It's under a tenner, the DVD extras are all intact, the picture quality is much improved and in some cases unbelievably so - and its eminently re-watchable.<br /><br />To sum up - if you're a fan of the film, Jane Austen or both - then you must own \\"Pride & Prejudice\\" on this format. A Blu Ray gem and highly recommended.around the scenes like a graceful swan.     In the cinema, it was a delight to look and experience - but sitting at home and watching it in real definition is a far more rewarding and illuminating experience. The acting chops on display is right across the board and apart from a slightly jarring ending, it had the hallmarks of a shoot that was fun and supremely confident in its delivery. I know others will cite the BBC production as definitive - but I think there's more than enough room on my shelf for both.     Matthew MacFadyen, Brenda Blethyn, Rosamund Pike, Carey Mulligan, Judy Dench, Tom Hollander - they were a cleverly chosen cast - and Rupert Friend won the heart of the lovely Kiera (which might explain the ethereal beauty of her performance). But it's the stunning adaptation of Jane Austen's novel by DEBORAH MOGGACH that is the real hero of the day. There is a sequence when Elizabeth and Darcy finally face off against each other in the rain - the dialogue is to die for - and should have been Oscar rewarded. As a dabbler in screenplays myself, I can't stress enough just how good the work here is - dazzling stuff.     It's under a tenner, the DVD extras are all intact, the picture quality is much improved and in some cases unbelievably so - and its eminently re-watchable.     To sum up - if you're a fan of the film, Jane Austen or both - then you must own \\"Pride & Prejudice\\" on this format. A Blu Ray gem and highly recommended.

Overall: A great film whose only problem is a decent to good story. Well worth spending your money on. And I hope you do. I will be seeing this again. I have read that they plan on making one more after this if it makes money and I hope it does because I want another film.    On a side not. I'm not a fan of 3D movies but the only opinion for my showing was in 3D so I had to. And to be honest it works for this film really well. So I might give it a chance in the future.

0385523912|2.0|If you are looking for insight into the normal lives of North Koreans I recommend this book.  However, please don't consider the 2 stars and my recommendation as a reflection on the author's ability to understand her own surroundings.  It seems like she does a fine job telling the stories of others, but the personal observations that she includes are so off base that I wonder whether I can trust her description of a place she has never truly laid eyes on.  Frankly, this book is only interesting when the author leaves her own impressions out.  I found myself completely annoyed every time the author tried to interject her own impression of Korea into the narrative.  Listening to her description of South Korea as rows of ugly boxes and KFC knock-offs really proved to me that she has the typical westerner's superficial knowledge of Korea, i.e. what a first time visitor sees on the cab ride from the airport.  Furthermore, she compares the traditional Korean attire for women to the Burka, which is absurd.  I felt as though she was stoking the flames of an ignorant fear ubiquitous in the United States.  The romanization of Korean words in the book are awful.  They follow neither the McCune-Reishchauer nor the Revised Romanization forms (Abeoji is spelled Abogi in the book...).  Thankfully when the writer simply conveys what she elicited from the interviewees, and leaves her personal observations out, this book is rather informative.

B002ZCY7SW|5.0|A quick note: the following review contains only minor spoilers concerning returning characters and storylines and does not disclose any major revelations.     Previously on 24: For 7 seasons the thriller genre was redefined and the bar for drama and suspense was raised to a new high, and not just for television. The brilliant, subversive and fearless writing staff, the deep cast of memorable characters, the always atmospheric scores of Sean Callery, and the inventive real-time format made for the greatest thrill ride in television history. 24 was not always flawless, in fact, there were moments that threatened to destroy its legacy (see season 6 for an example), but for the most part, 24 ranged from great to masterful (see season 5). So naturally, us fans, who already had ridiculously high standards for our beloved series expected pure, unrelenting excellence from its 8th and final season...    Day 8: The POTUS is working with the president of the fictional middle-eastern country Kamistan (think Iran) at the UN to put forth an unprecedented peace agreement. Jack Bauer, now healthy and watching cartoons with his granddaughter is pulled back into the action when an old informant literally knocks on his door. All he has to do is survive one last day...     The change of setting to New York City was a wise choice. Not only does it make sense for a rogue agent like Bauer to be on the move, major changes of any kind seem natural for a show that focuses on its characters literally one day at a time. Also, after so many years in LA it would have seemed stagnant to have stayed in DC or to have returned to the show's original location. There isn't nearly as much on location work as I expected but the CGI backdrops are, for the most part, very well done and the new setting adds a nice refreshing quality to the series (much like DC did in season seven).     Though many fans were critical of the season's slower, season 1 style start, it allows the time for the stage to be set before the plot really takes off. Yes, season 5 started off with a bang and never let up, but it isn't necessary for every season to do the same. The Hassan family is a perfect example of how to not rush a storyline. President Omar Hassan gets the screen time that is usually allotted to the American president. This ends up being well worth it. His arc as well as the arc of his family and the peace treaty ends up being one of the most well written storylines in the entire run of the series. It is riveting, fearless, complex and in typical 24 fashion, it is edgy, unabated and is not prone to sappiness or contrived revelations. Again, like most of the season, it starts off slow, but it consistently heats up and eventually catches fire.    The threat that propels the first half of the story is pretty familiar, as are the villains. The difference is that the threat comes together after several episodes of building towards it rather than just out of thin air in the first hour, and the villains actually have some political motives and larger intentions rather than just being driven by the desire to destroy. These two things may sound minor but they are absolutely key in separating the threat/villains of Day 8 from the very, very similar ones of previous years. Hint: all the other evenly numbered seasons.    Season 8 sees the return of CTU, which in a way, feels like a regression. But it does provide a familiar, nostalgic feel for the final season, and more importantly it allows for Chloe O' Brien to once again be a series regular. The new CTU is visually impressive, making CTU LA look like a concrete garage, though its return does unfortunately come with some recycled subplots and generic characters. Brian Hastings, the new director isn't nearly as terrible as most fans claim he is, but he is very bland and could never be mentioned in the same sentence as George Mason or Bill Buchanan. Freddie Prince Jr. is actually surprisingly decent as Cole Ortiz, the head of field ops.Yet none of the new editions are even half as memorable as past CTU alumni like Tony Almeida,  Michelle Dessler, or Curtis Manning.   The Dana Walsh story is without a doubt the biggest flaw of season 8. An irrelevant subplot about a CTU analyst fending off blackmailing rednecks from her past sounds like an obvious bad idea but somehow it ended up with a disturbingly large amount of screen time. Ultimately, if you're incredibly patient, her story gains some momentum but it never redeems itself (going from annoying to unoriginal) and will always be analogous to the Kim's wacky adventures in season two.     As mentioned above, Chloe is once again a series regular, and not only does she get plenty of screen time, she also gets a good amount of character development and unlike some of the previous seasons, she's allowed to once again take center stage... where she belongs. Basically, season 8 is a great day for Chloe fans, second only to season 5.              24 has always done a brilliant job of adding interesting twists to their recurring characters in each new season; Renee Walker's return season 8 is no exception. Since the events of Day 7, when she was pushed from an honest, law abiding agent to a Bauer-esque renegade, she has fallen into a very dark place. In season 8 she is broken, vulnerable and at times, borderline psychotic. This makes for a string of shocking episodes reminiscent of those classic hours in Days 1 and 2 when we found out for the first time just how much of a loose cannon, badass Jack Bauer really is. Her involvement also adds a great deal of emotional depth to the season as her relationship with Jack starts to evolve.     President Taylor returns as well, though, for the first part of the season she is pushed to the background. Though it seems strange at first, it ultimately makes perfect sense... it allows the necessary room for the Hassan storyline to develop which sets the stage for later episodes, when the spotlight shifts to Taylor, setting up one of the season's most riveting stories, with a tremendous performance by Cherry Jones. It may take a while to heat up but her story arc in Day 8 ends up being right there with the best of 24's presidential storylines, and in a series that featured both David Palmer and Charles Logan, that's really saying something.     Speaking of 24's former presidents, Day 8 also sees the return of Logan, and this time its not just for a three episode long subplot. Gregory Itzin is outstanding once again and his presence alone takes the season to another level. His return is full of all the twists, drama and electric standoffs you could hope for. It doesn't matter how high your expectations are for the Charles Logan story, you will not be disappointed.      Some have criticized season 8 for not adding enough depth to Jack's role in the season's first half. Yes, even Jack going through the motions would make for a decent season, but it would be a real stretch to say that this is the case here. At most it could be said that Jack is a touch removed from the first half of the day's events, but part of this is because Jack really doesn't want to be involved in the first place; that is what adds depth to his involvement. He now has something to live for and it is interesting to see how that impacts his desire to plunge back into his old save-the-day lifestyle. It's also important to realize that much of Bauer's story arc in Day 8 is directly tied with the return of Renee. After Day 7 Jack was pulled out of his former world by his daughter, who saved his life and his new-born granddaughter, and aside from his loyalty to Chloe, it is only because of Renee that he ventures back into that world, and throughout the day it is mainly her presence that keeps him there. And to anyone that does feel that Jack is not featured to his full potential in the season's first half, you needn't worry. The last half of Day 8 is without doubt the most intense Jack Bauer story line we have seen. Itis Bauer completely off the chain, held back by nothing and no one, literally going against the entire world. It is shocking and spellbinding, even by 24 standards. A hell of a way to end the series.    Another positive quality of Day 8 is the feeling of renewed creativity. There is an energy to this season that is reminiscent of the early days. There are far less of the stale, predictable interrogation scenes and more opportunities for Jack to use intellect and creativity to track down suspects and get them talk. There are more moments that feel fresh and exciting rather than run of the mill. Yes, there are some predictable twists and a few revelations that seem a bit too familiar. But there are still moments when even the most seasoned 24 fan will be left shocked and speechless, still plenty of story arcs that will keep you just as addicted as you were to season one, and there are still enough 24-style emotional powerhouse moments that will leave you floored again and again. Even during some of the moments when you see what's coming you will be thinking \\"Yes, this is the 24 I know and love!\\" way more often than you'll be thinking \\"I've seen this before.\\" And even when you are thinking the latter you will at least have to give credit to the writers for finding an entirely new twist to put on it. Sure, there are many exceptions which I will leave to you to find yourself but they aren't nearly enough to put a damper on the entire season.     The scores of Sean Callery are also a must-mention. The music of series has always been an immensely crucial aspect of the 24's atmosphere and intensity. Day 8 is no different. The scores are as atmospheric and fitting as ever.    So, how does Day 8 work as an end to the series? Well, unlike other shows, 24 seasons work mostly as stand-alones. For this reason it is hard to judge #8 as a final season. The series finale may not quite have the emotional stopping power of the season 1 finale or the explosiveness of the season 5 finale but it is still epic and amazing all the way through. Classic 24 without a doubt. And though there may be a lot of differing opinions about whether or not it was a truly fitting end to the (television) adventures of Jack Bauer, no one can deny that the final few hours of the series are 24 at its very best. And for me, that alone is satisfying enough. The bottom line is that #8 lives up to the standards of quality and groundbreaking originality set by the previous years and though other seasons are debatably better, #8 is no more than a notch or two lower. Despite its many flaws, Jack Bauer's final day of mayhem is definitely in the upper echelon of 24 seasons.

B002ZG980U|4.0|As soon as I finished watching Inception the first comparison that came to my mind was William Gibson's [[ASIN:0441012035 Neuromancer]].  There's some superficial plot similarities between the two, but what struck me about both was how many really cool images and ideas both had.  It also struck me that despite all of the awesome action, elaborate set pieces and cool moments, both Neuromancer and Inception failed to connect with me on anything other than a purely visceral level.  Inception fails in the same way Neuromancer did.  It's too focused on the various plot machinations and rules that govern it's universe, and it fails to give the character side of the equation as much loving attention.       First with the superlatives.  This is a very entertaining and exciting movie.  I was particularly impressed with Christopher Nolan's staging of the action sequences.  I found a lot of the Dark Knight's big set pieces to be too messy.  There was a lot of quick cuts and choppy sequences.  Inception's action sequences didn't seem to have this problem.  I also found a few scenes incredibly imaginative.  The hallway scene in particular was very well staged and thought out.  Most importantly, the action felt much more clear and purposeful than in his Batman films.      The ideas in Inception are also very promising.  I enjoy films about dreams because they afford filmmakers the opportunity to get completely lost inside someones head.  Inception doesn't really use the dreams to examine psychology too deeply.  Rather they're used as elaborate staging grounds for mind bending action.  I liked the different take on dreams, and it made for some very good action sequences.      Now for some criticisms.  A lot of sci-fi seems to focus to much on the world it's building and not enough on the characters who inhabit the world.  Cobb is given a tortured back story about his wife, but the relationship between the two never moved me in any kind of way.  It's seemed typically Hollywood to me, and it felt out of place among all of the unconventional ideas and set pieces.      And what about the rest of the team?  Besides Robert Fischer, who gets quite a bit of back story and motivation, the rest of the team are basically cyphers.  I would have appreciated a bit more characterization of Arthur or Eames to flesh out why I should care about these folks.      Inception is an entertaining movie with a lot of great action sequences.  Technically, it's a brilliant piece of film making.  Nolan knows how to entertain and please a crowd.  You should see this if you're at all a fan of action films.  I've avoided any interpretation here, but it's worth checking out online some of the theories and explanation about how the film works.      I have one minor quibble about the DVD.  I got the bear bones DVD edition at a gift exchange, and I believe that the dialogue is mixed too quiet while the music and the sound effects are mixed to loud.  I had to turn up the volume to hear the characters talk but turn it down when there was an explosion in an attempt to not piss off my neighbors.
B00192IV9U|3.0|No matter how you feel about Michael Jackson, let's just call this album what it is...a rushed, stitched-together cash-in.  Just about everything in this album reeks of that. The album is really short...Jackson's albums since Dangerous have contained between 14 and 16 tracks.  The packaging is painfully bland as well.  And finally, the music.  These picks are clearly not up to par with what Michael Jackson would've released.  And dare I say, some songs require some imagination on the listener's part to even admit it's Jackson himself singing!  The rest of the songs sound like third-rate outtakes.  The polish that Jackson carefully gives to his records is missing completely here.  There is no coherence, no concept, and no spirit.  Probably the best song on the album is \\"Behind The Mask\\", which was recorded during the Thriller sessions!  The worst thing is that now this album tarnishes what is an incredible music legacy.  It might provide some decent listening, but ultimately it is utterly forgettable.    1. Hold My Hand (featuring Akon) - This is a decent enough track, but Akon overpowers it entirely.    2. Hollywood Tonight - This would be a fantastic song if it wasn't for the questionable vocals.  Jackson's voice is really deep...it doesn't sound like him at all, and you wonder just how much trickery is involved.    3. Keep Your Head Up - A pretty uninteresting song with obvious studio meddling.  Jackson's vibratto sounds way off.    4. (I Like) The Way You Love Me - This is basically the same exact song you heard on Jackson's Ultimate Collection box set with an excerpt of Jackson in the studio added at the start.  Why this was included here is beyond me.    5. Monster (featuring 50 Cent) - Like 'Hollywood Tonight', this doesn't sound like Jackson.  It's also a chock full of vocal samples edited haphazardly together.    6. Best of Joy - One of the more genuine-sounding songs on this album.  Supposedly this was one of the very last songs he recorded in his life.7. Breaking News - There is nothing interesting or redeeming about this song.  It is awful in every way.    8. (I Can't Make It) Another Day (featuring Lenny Kravitz) - Another decent song.  One of the highlights here.    9. Behind The Mask - This song is awesome.  Plain and simple.  Jackson sounds youthful and full of energy, and the production is really excellent.    10. Much Too Soon - This song bored me to tears.  An awful way to end a record.    I'm sure that the Michael Jackson Estate, who actually released this album, is busy readying another one.  There are scores of unreleased Michael Jackson songs being leaked to the internet, many of which are infinitely better than the ones on this album.  Hopefully they'll do a better job with that one...

030746363X|5.0|I've actually read this book twice now -- a pre-pre-draft a few months ago and the final copy more recently. I'm not a \\"fitness guy,\\" in fact I had never been to the gym in my life besides a few minutes on a treadmill, and when my friends would talk about running or biking I felt like it was some sort of club I should to have learned about when I was a kid but never did. But I was fine, I got by on a fast metabolism and a ready supply of bad puns.    The first thing that struck me in the book, besides Tim's signature anecdotes, was how there wasn't a \\"this is the one true way\\" tone to it. It was very matter-of-fact: here's what I learned from the research, here's what I tried, here's what worked and what didn't, here's what the experts said, here's something to try. Being a geek, and a skeptic, every part of that appealed to me and I did something I'd never done before in my life -- I started to pay attention to my physical well-being.    First I started with some measurements to get a baseline, then the diet parts of the book (man I love that cheat day), next I began doing kettlebell workouts. Before I knew it, friends and colleagues were starting to notice and I found myself shopping for some slimmer-fitting clothes. Even better, though, was I began to find day-to-day tasks just a bit more effortless, like carrying and lifting my bag in my frequent travel, taking the stairs instead of the escalators, and helping my parents put up their giant Christmas tree.    It's hard to summarize, but what this book did that nothing before it was able to do was just get me off my butt and away from my computer screen. I don't know if it was the volume of information, the way it took an analytical approach, or just the hooks of the counter-intuitive findings, but it worked. I now lead a much more balanced life, and even though I didn't (and probably will never) apply every chapter of the book, I like knowing that I have them as reference if I ever need them.    P.S. If you're ageek and want to learn how exercise improves your mental acuity, which I also found very motivating, check out the first chapter of [[ASIN:0979777747 John Medina's Brain Rules]].

142311339X|5.0|Riordan is a master at depicting realistic characters that readers care about and placing them in far-out, fantasy settings and situations. It's not an easy feat that few authors have been able to pull off (Robert Liparulo and his Dreamhouse Kings series is another good example of doing it right). The result is a story that's edge-of-your-seat exciting and easy to get lost in. Like some other reviewers here, I was skeptical of Riordan's ability to continue in the Percy Jackson world without becoming a bit boring. I shouldn't have worried. Obviously, he was aware of that possibility and avoided it with fresh characters and plot twists. Even his writing was fresh and once again I remembered why I like reading him so much. Great writer and storyteller. If you haven't read any of his books, you're really missing out. While I think you should read his previous series first, if this is your first, you'll still enjoy it and I predict you'll be going back to get all of his books.

While Stallone and Statham are clearly \\"the stars,\\" there are also over a dozen other \\"supporting stars\\" -- and The Expendables has to give each one of those stars enough screen time to establish his character, to make us like him enough that we care if he lives or dies, and to let him feature in at least one cool scene. That's a HUGE chunk of time spent doing nothing but rolling out characters. It didn't add anything to the plot (mainly because there WAS no plot), while it really cut into the action.<br /><br />And even when there was good action, the director filmed the biggest scenes in the dark, using shaky-cams. So I could tell that someone was shooting, but didn't have a prayer of figuring out who was shooting who. The introductory hostage rescue, and the assault at the end, both suffered from this. My TV has pretty good contrast, but I don't like having to rewind every 60 seconds to figure out what just happened.<br /><br />The remaining action scenes were good, mind you! A solid car chase or two, some nice martial arts action, and even an old-fashioned streetfight on a basketball court -- all the kind of stuff I expected. If the whole film were able to keep that level of over-the-top, cinematic action, it would've been great.<br /><br />(Alternatively, it could've had a good plot, instead of one that made absolutely no sense. \\"The villain kidnaps the girl before escaping -- why? I just wish I'd gotten it.)

The book gives a rich background to his life in Malawi, and it helps the reader -most who are unknowlegable about true life in an African nation, a better understanding of just how difficult his task and achievment was. They took out a whole other melody that played and changed the piano sounds into ones that sound like they came from a cheap Fisher Price toy. Whoever thought that this version was superior to the one that was released on the original box set should be shot. Someone like my mother, who loves MJ, would listen to this album and say, \\"This is Michael? Doesn't sound like it.\\" Even I could produce a better album than this!! B00004BZ16|5.0|December 12, 1980: The morning after the historic release by The Clash of that out-of-the-park grand slam called London Calling at the fag-end of 1979, a bargain-priced double-LP in which \\"the only band that matters\\" from UK punk's Class of '77 stretched out and into an at least half-dozen further genres (rockabilly, roots rock, reggae, ska, calypso, honky-tonk, rhythm-and-blues) because they could and knew it, Joe Strummer, Mick Jones, Paul Simonon, and Topper Headon must have asked themselves, Wot now for a bleedin' encore, lads? before decamping to NYC, land of historic ballparks, the better for yet another pointing-armed Bambino swing for the fences - where London Calling ran to 18 songs (19 with the unbilled closer \\"Train in Vain\\", a favorite of many a fan), Sandinista! saw them and doubled them to 36.    Though the stuffed-to-burst trifection - on the aptly-labeled CBS offshoot, Epic - did, like its deathless lead-in a year prior, top the annual \\"Pazz and Jop\\" critics' poll at the Village Voice two months after its December 12 release (though with three-eighths fewer distributed, proportionally-represented votes), much of the critical consensus ever since was summed in the thumbnail review penned by the paper's greybeard rock critic Robert Christgau, who in his monthly Consumer Guide roundup dropped The Clash from the A+ he gave London Calling down to an A-minus:    \\"...note...that the many good songs aren't as consistently compelling as on previous Clash albums...and conclude that if this is their worst--which it is, I think--they must be, er, the world's greatest rock and roll band.\\"    From the first track, \\"The Magnificent Seven\\", a driving bass-fueled forward-marching rap cut, the band's determination to claim yet more generic territory was plain and not in vain, as was Strummer's immersion then and there in the early works issuing from the then-new rap genre of Grandmaster Flash and the Furious Five, and The Sugar Hill Gang. The song stands as the firstexposure of the mainstream rock audience to rap, and in its spoofing of wage-slaving consumerism on levels both serious and playful, has served countless Clash fans as the Platonic jolt of audio caffeine with which to greet each new day bidding them shuffle their sleepy way toward the Man's punch-clock:    Ring ring! Seven AM  Move yourself to go again  Cold water in the face  Brings you back to this awful place  Knuckle merchants and you bankers too  Must get out there and learn those rules  Weather man and the crazy chief  One says sun and one says sleet  AM the FM the PM too  Churnin' out that boogaloo    In training their trademark lyrical obsessions upon the worldwide subordinations of class and race, with the aid of their love of the larger-than-life imagery of the Hollywood western, the Jamaican outlaw mystique and the boasting royalism of calyp-synched nomenclature (all hail Lord Strummer!), the band became the sonic CNN of the early 1980s, exulting in the recent and externally-unmolested Nicaraguan revolution of the year before, and scoring along the way imperialisms western and Soviet (\\"Washington Bullets\\"), the stubborn longevity of English class prejudice (\\"Something About England\\", a likely seedbed for Mick Jones' stirring immigrant-friendly anthem \\"Beyond the Pale\\" off No. 10, Upping St. when later fronting Big Audio Dynamite),    There was masters an' servants an' servants an' dogs  They taught you how to touch your cap  Through strikes and famine and war and peace  England never closed this gap    the squalid murder of hope of council-block housing (\\"Up in Heaven [Not Only Here]\\"), police brutality in the inner city (\\"Corner Soul\\" and \\"Police on My Back\\", the latter an Eddy Grant cover), the devaluation of individual life by street criminals (\\"Somebody Got Murdered\\"), the cold hypocrisies of the holyroller-than-thou (\\"The Sound of the Sinners\\", a respectful gospel parody), and America's nightmare history with race (\\"One More Time\\"):    Yeah, you don't need no silicone  To calculate poverty  Watch when Watts town burns again  The bus goes to Montgomery    By now, Joe Strummer was, in his family-of-man decency, well on his way to becoming \\"the George Orwell of rock, a delicate mix of unforgiving skepticism for both sides and honest empathy for the downtrodden.\\" And along with the globe-girdling scenes of social struggle of the sort that had marked like songs on London Calling, came a newer warmth of tone audible in each of the songs just mentioned, deepening the emotional range of a band that had just a year before, on an album projecting exhilarating defiance on the public face of a quartet of implacable world-conquering centurions on the march, managed to carry its softer domestic habits of the political heart fairly well concealed (\\"Guns of Brixton\\" was not exactly Music to Tickle Baby's Chin By). In a like vein, the injection on several tracks (\\"Hitsville UK\\", \\"Corner Soul\\") of vocal estrogen courtesy Mick Jones' then-partner Ellen Foley, previously best known for backing vocals on \\"Paradise By the Dashboard Light\\" by Meat Loaf, and later for such among her Hollywood roles as Billie on Night Court, does have the otherwise-rare effect of rendering a band best thought of hitherto as deserving of comradely fraternal handshakes, or perhaps, after a Red wine or three, Brezhnev-meets-Honecker cheekpecks, positively squeezeworthy.    The divers genre-bending bonfires of the novelties across Sandinista!, from dub to disco to jazz, do vary as much as the album-cubed's reputation well indicates, and there will always be across its three dozen tracks lulls in relative affection, from Jamaican dub star Mikey Dread's interstitial*    *[And indecipherable, as on, e.g., \\"The Crooked Beat\\":    \\"I had always wondered who the dog, Weinstein was.\\"    \\"And why they named a lane after him.\\"]    singsong rasps to Paul Simonon's monotone trudge through what some have thought of as the aptly- if \\"unwittily\\"-named track \\"The CrookedBeat\\", when even the most bunkered Clashman and his dragon will echo as one Joe's cry toward the end of \\"The Magnificent Seven\\" - \\"It's [...]' long, innit?\\"    But no matter. Whether or not it was your sprawling intro to the band, as it was for me 29 years ago next March on the Michigan-to-Manhattan spring break of a life-changing-time, Sandinista! has had a way for thirty years as of Sunday of, in one way or another, becoming an event in the lives of all of its listeners, however much we might, er, Clash among ourselves on all other matters nonmusical, calling to indelible memory where we were at the time and what we were about, scratch our heads bald though we might as to the whys and the wherefores.    Not bad for a foursome that, the year before, when not otherwise engaged making musical history, was getting nicked for shooting pigeons on London rooftops. And though Joe may have met \\"Death\\" far too soon, he and his, er, Clashmates managed to leave the rest of us enough \\"Glory\\" to slip all risk of wearing out its groove this side of Rock and Roll Heaven - and the Vinyl Judgment.

1449389627|5.0|[Disclaimer: I got this book for free as part of the Oreilly blogger review program]<br /><br />If you are keen observer of speeches given by CEO's or anyone from upper management in your organization, the word \\"innovation\\" will come out often. But whether, the real meaning of the word \\"innovation\\" is understood or not is a different story, and this is the central theme of \\"The Myths of Innovation\\" book.<br /><br />The Myths of Innovation starts from the history of innovation and takes the readers through the fundamentals, methods of innovation, human side of innovation, that is how people will receive any new ideas and how to be successful in reaching out.<br /><br />Author also debunks the idea of one super man or woman creates something really good and saves the world every innovation is the combination of existing ideas but seen differently buy an innovator and when the puzzle fits together, new solutions emerge.<br /><br />The second part of the book concentrates on the myth of boss knows everything. But  the truth is no one can think through that much in future. Management concentrates on controlling and getting the job done, and one cannot innovate in such an environment. This point is very loud and clear, if your organization wants to encourage workers to identify problems and find innovative solutions then, this type of command and control management style will not work.<br /><br />This book also goes in-depth on why certain ideas flourish and easily adopted but others fail. The key here is, instead of changing the status quo, if the innovative solution builds on top of what people already know, adoption will be much faster. Example, mobile phones. People were already using telephones and cordless. The learning curve to use a mobile phone is also pretty straight forward, this lead to their adoption a great success.<br /><br />Then there is problem and solution. An Idea can solve a problem and at the same time, a solution might be so advanced, it's not been adopted and waiting for its problem to emerge.<br /><br />There can be solutions that finds way out due to the side effects of an research. Microwave Oven was a byproduct after Dr. Percy Spencer found out about this when he was doing some other research.<br /><br />The message is, be open to ideas, do through research on defining the problem and then work on the solution.<br />Epilogue part hits the nail on clearly explaining on how to develop your creative thinking, How to pitch an idea and how to stay motivated. This part is the actual implementation plan for anyone who wants to be a creative thinker and develop something new.<br /><br />Overall, I rate this book as highly recommended for anyone want to learn about innovation and if you are new to the concept of innovation, thank god you found this book as in my humble opinion, you will not get a better introduction in this subject than this one.There can be solutions that finds way out due to the side effects of an research. Microwave Oven was a byproduct after Dr. Percy Spencer found out about this when he was doing some other research.    The message is, be open to ideas, do through research on defining the problem and then work on the solution.  Epilogue part hits the nail on clearly explaining on how to develop your creative thinking, How to pitch an idea and how to stay motivated. This part is the actual implementation plan for anyone who wants to be a creative thinker and develop something new.    Overall, I rate this book as highly recommended for anyone want to learn about innovation and if you are new to the concept of innovation, thank god you found this book as in my humble opinion, you will not get a better introduction in this subject than this one.
B000HBKCDC|5.0|The problem with many (most?) contemporary-artist Christmas albums is that the artists just pump out a collection of Christmas standards in order to have one--there's seldom any real artistry involved. They may sing perkier, up the tempo, or add instrumentation (all well-covered by Anne Murray in the '70s and Amy Grant in the the '80s), but there's little to distinguish them above the many fine recordings of those same songs from the '60s, '50s, and earlier. One notable exception is this album by Sarah McLachlan (released in 2008), which includes standards, one original piece, and some contemporary covers (including some unexpected choices).    Among the standards, \\"What Child Is This?\\" is particularly well-refreshed, with decending minor chord progressions in the verses (as opposed to the original ascending major chord progressions) and smaller variations in the chorus, both of which are strikingly beautiful and flattering of Sarah McLachlan's atypical vocalization. \\"The First Noel\\" is given a similarly-original treatment, again to very pleasing effect. The other standards (I'll Be Home for Christmas, O Little Town of Bethlehem, Silent Night, Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas, In the Bleak Midwinter, Christmas Time Is Here) are closer to the traditional arrangements, but with tempo variations and vocal arrangements that make them sound equally fresh and enchanting.    The original contribution, the title cut \\"Wintersong,\\" is more of a winter-themed love song rather than a Christmas tune, but is pleasant-sounding and sufficiently sentimental to fit in well on this album.    Of the contemporary covers, \\"Happy Xmas (War Is Over)\\" is presented pretty much as John Lennon originally recorded it (though I find Sarah's voice easier to listen to); if you liked the original, you'll like this rendition. One unexpected selection is an updated version of Joni Mitchell's \\"River\\" (since included on other contemporary Christmas albums); the connection to Christmas is rather oblique (references to skating on a frozen river; what's next, a cover of Jethro Tull's \\"Skating Away\\"?), but if you like the song, you'll appreciate this arrangement.    Of greater interest in the realm of the unexpected (at least to me) is the hauntingly beautiful presentation of Gordon Lightfoot's \\"Song For a Winter's Night\\" (from the '70s, for those of you who aren't old enough to have heard the original). I had never thought of this as a Christmas song (nor is it any more so than \\"Wintersong\\"), but this track about brings me to tears every time I hear it, so I'm so glad it's on this album! It's also heartening to me that Sarah McLachlan would think to include such a tender, well-rendered tribute to a fellow Canadian singer-songwriter from an earlier era. Do yourself a favor, and listen to the original for comparison [...]

B0041KKYEM|4.0|When we tried to see this, every showing was sold out -except for the very last one of the evening. So we bought our tickets, strolled around a mall, and waited eagerly to view the film. It was worth the wait even though the movie had some significant flaws (more about that soon). I do understand why Natalie Portman has gotten much acclaim for her role as Nina, a young ballerina who seems to be on the rise to stardom. She might even win an Oscar for her performance. The role is extremely demanding and it is clear that she worked hard to get her body to fit the part, looking particularly thin (as many ballerinas do, almost anorexic). She also stretched her acting chops and took significant risks, including some fairly graphic sexual scenes as well as a believable depiction of a young woman with an unhinged mind.<br /><br />However, I felt very ambivalent about this film and wasn't the only one. Audiences leaving the theater were either talking positively about the film or giving it a thumbs down. Portman is superb when revealing how she tries to dig deeply within herself to portray both the White and Black Swan. The part of the White Swan comes easily to her but the darker, riskier role of the Black Swan taxes her emotionally. Nina is assured that she has the moves of an experienced ballerina. But she is criticized by the ballet company's director for her inability to bring passion to the role of the Black Swan.<br /><br />Dance fans will find a wealth of stunning choreography and insight into some parts of the world of ballet. Even those who aren't fond of ballet should be entranced by the dance scenes. I certainly was. But there seemed to be too many stereotypes. Barbara Hershey is usually a reliable actress but she seems to be off kilter here, being the overprotective mother. Nina's desire to be \\"perfect\\" resonates beyond the movie and serves as a reminder of how dancers often turn to self-destructive acts to stay in shape - throwing up, being anorexic or bulemic and more. In that regard, Nina could be at an extreme end of a spectrum of mental illness that may be all too prevalent in the dance world...although not as over the top as Nina (or let's hope not).<br /><br />Suspense is definitely created during scenes when it is hard to separate Nina's truth from fantasy. What is Nina actually seeing and what is an illusion? In some parts of the movie it is clear that she is hallucinating...in others, not so much so. In the end, I couldn't quite buy this as a psychological drama but thought it veered closer to a horror movie. Parts of this film were extremely painful to watch and if you have trouble watching someone in physical pain, including plenty of blood, consider yourself forewarned. There were plenty of gasps and moans from the audience during the particularly gruesome scenes.<br /><br />In the end, I couldn't help wondering: will this movie stand the test of time? Odds are high that viewers will always be entranced by the very lovely Natalie Portman. But will the movie's theme and plot development seem credible during repeat viewings? Only time will tell whether this becomes a classic dance and psychological/horror film or simply a temporary sensation.that regard, Nina could be at an extreme end of a spectrum of mental illness that may be all too prevalent in the dance world...although not as over the top as Nina (or let's hope not).     Suspense is definitely created during scenes when it is hard to separate Nina's truth from fantasy. What is Nina actually seeing and what is an illusion? In some parts of the movie it is clear that she is hallucinating...in others, not so much so. In the end, I couldn't quite buy this as a psychological drama but thought it veered closer to a horror movie. Parts of this film were extremely painful to watch and if you have trouble watching someone in physical pain, including plenty of blood, consider yourself forewarned. There were plenty of gasps and moans from the audience during the particularly gruesome scenes.     In the end, I couldn't help wondering: will this movie stand the test of time? Odds are high that viewers will always be entranced by the very lovely Natalie Portman. But will the movie's theme and plot development seem credible during repeat viewings? Only time will tell whether this becomes a classic dance and psychological/horror film or simply a temporary sensation.
